title: South Asia: 1.5C Impacts, Ground Connection, and Resilience
description:
Big thanks Dr. Muhammad Ittefaq @ScienceTalkOfficial for this interview.  Dr. Ittefaq consulted me on last week's coverage of South Asia's climate outlook- link below.  We recorded this interview on Monday, 12/15, and I have found myself thinking about what I learned from him all this week.  

For those of us working to grow our understanding, I think it is very important to understand not only our domestic outlook, but also global impacts and outlooks.  In South Asia, there is no debate.  1.5C impacts are unfolding as expected.  I deeply value the information and perspectives Dr. Ittefaq has shared in this recording both as an academic in public health, and as a person whose resilient community of origin and family are experiencing intense, repeated disaster.

South Asia Outlook: https://youtu.be/J2KhLx-61fE

~~~~~~~

title: International Climate Outlooks: South Asia
description:
This international outlook video focuses on 2C modeling for Pakistan, India, and Bangladesh.  We'll look at contemporary, observed changes to climate in South Asia as we stand now at 1.5C, and learn about projected changes to temperature, precipitation, and other water factors.  This densely populated region is experiencing substantial change at 1.5C.  This difficult outlook will impact the lived experience of a quarter of humanity.  Be a jerk in the comments?  Get banned.

title: UK and Ireland: Climate Projection Update
description:
The UK is looking at really different climate outcomes depending on if the Gulf Stream collapses or not.  In recent Earth Systems Updates, we've seen evidence that that whole system is looking pretty wobbly.   Many people are aware that without the warmth from the Gulf Stream, the UK would be looking at intense cold.  The question is, how cold are we talking?  

In this video we explore the risk spread for the UK and Ireland as we look to 2C of global warming in both AMOC up and AMOC down scenarios.  First we look at sea level rise, sea ice, then projected changes in temperature and precipitation.  Our exploration begins with a focus on Edinburgh and the northern Scottish coast, with additional detailing for London, Liverpool, and London.  

I highly recommend using these global resources to check out the change spread for your home:

https://coastal.climatecentral.org/

https://amocscenarios.org/

title: Science in a Low Energy Future: What Could We Save?
description: Popular imaginings of the future tend to go either high tech or total collapse.  In this video I share some books from my library as we explore possibilities around surprisingly old, pre-computer medical breakthroughs, including insulin production, antitoxins, and antibiotics.  Thinking about the future in ways that are not confined by high-tech visioning can open unexpected quality of life possibilities.

description:
In my last update before the nation overview next week, I wanted to share some thoughts about place.  Deciding where to go is a big question on many people's minds, and while I quite obviously think the climate outlook information is very important, it's far from the only thing that matters.  Before I share my analysis on that climate outlook information, I wanted to share my reasoning about how this information is best used, as we make decisions about our lives in this time of change.

At the endcap, I give info about our quarterly newsletter.  If you want to sign up, scroll down at this link- & I'll show you where to find it in the video.

description:

Folks, I think Montana is so beautiful.  Conditions in Montana are pretty hard, people are already hurting.  I do my best here to describe my sense of the feeling on the ground in this report.

title: July 7, '25.  Tipping Point, Meaning & Action
description:
Folks, there is very serious observational evidence that has recently been published.

Fairly clear language:
https://www.icm.csic.es/en/news/change-southern-ocean-structure-can-have-climate-implications
Journal article: 
https://www.pnas.org/doi/10.1073/pnas.2500440122

I find this to be clear physical evidence that we are in a tipping point, which is a position I have maintained since March of '24.  In this video I talk about what it means to want to be alive through this tipping point, and I re-iterate how my work over the past year and a half has been focused on providing our community with what guideposts may be helpful in this time of fundamental uncertainty.  So there are resources here on the channel that may help you.  But fundamentally, I hope you respond to this significant news by reflecting on personal meaning.

title: Northern Great Plains Overview: Cross-Model Climate Projections
description:
In this regional series we're bringing the cross-model approach used in the "Lifeboats" video all around the US. This final regional video before the national outlook focuses on the Northern Great Plains, including Nebraska, Wyoming, South Dakota, North Dakota, and Montana. 

The three main threads we'll use to explore impacts in this region are hot season changes, projected precipitation change, and changes to the cold, including both snowpack and winter lows. 

The Northern Great Plains has one of the best regional outlooks in the nation. I felt happy putting together this video for my neighbors to the west- anyone who cares about American food security in these times of change will be interested in this video! 

Here are a number of resources I reference in the video: https://www.americanresiliency.org/ 
-stable visualizations & support our work 

https://nca2023.globalchange.gov/ 
-for figures & atlas 

https://climate.copernicus.eu/climate-bulletins 
-short & clear background info 

https://www.regenerativefarmersofamerica.com/regenerative-farmers-of-america-blog/pearl-millet 
-some great intro info for pearl millet 

https://www.researchgate.net/publication/361134395_Interbasin_and_interhemispheric_impacts_of_a_collapsed_Atlantic_Overturning_Circulation/link/633621dc76e39959d6857360/download 
-for AMOC figures

title: June '25 Earth Systems Update
description:
Last week we received the Copernicus bulletin for May numbers, with good news regarding a sizable drop in global temps.  But I don't feel so good about it, as patterns in sea ice and sea surface temperatures are starting to look too much like the prelude to the '23 jump.  I hope that when I do the next Earth Systems Update in October that my concerns will be laid to rest.  In this update, I try to look at both sides of the coin- both the big picture positive signs and the potentially concerning signs emerging in earth systems today.

Copernicus Bulletin:  (I use several unusual figures from this bulletin)
https://climate.copernicus.eu/surface-air-temperature-may-2025

Climate Reanalyzer: (for SSTs and daily maps)
https://climatereanalyzer.org/

Antarctic Ice:
https://zacklabe.com/antarctic-sea-ice-extentconcentration/

Interview with Zack about personal & field DOGE cut impacts:
https://www.highnorthnews.com/en/us-climate-researcher-we-are-tipping-point

title: Northeast Overview: Cross-Model Climate Projections
description:
In this regional series we're bringing the cross-model approach used in the "Lifeboats" video all around the US.  This video focuses on the Northeast, and the three main threads we use to explore regional impacts are sea level rise, hot season increase, and deluge-type rain.  Much of the Northeast has great cool summer preservation, which offsets some of the region's anticipated water-related challenges.  You'll see that alongside major infrastructure challenges, there's enormous resilience potential in this region.

These worksheets are really cool imho.  You might want to download them before you watch the video.  Go to the bottom of the "resources" tab on our website to find the link where you can download all the materials.

title: Hazards Beyond Climate: Ticks & Infectious Disease
description:
When we look at the climate projections, of course living things are going to be on the move- including species of ticks that carry disease.

In this video I teach you how to ID disease-carrying ticks that are moving into new habitats, as well as how to recognize diseases they carry.  This is especially significant info for people on the west coast, in the Northeast, and in the northern Midwest.

I have an infectious disease background but I'm not a medical doctor, so AR community member & physician Dr. J has fact checked this script.  She also provides a little bird flu update that I share in this video, and she recommends these resources for folks who are interested in emerging infectious disease: 

The CIRDRAP website is great, and you can subscribe to their newsletter on the page:

https://www.cidrap.umn.edu/

And here's the signup link for the Brown Pandemic Center's weekly newsletter:

https://mailchi.mp/brown/tracking-report-subscription

title: Volunteer Spotlight: Jackie's Viz Project
description:
In this video Jackie Ryan takes us under the hood of her visualization of the NCA5 datasets.  This is the rare conversation where I enjoyed it even more listening again while I got the footage ready for release- everything she says connects in interesting ways.  If you're short on time, from about minute 17 Jackie describes the (incredible) next stage of the work she wants to do & makes a call for others to join her volunteer team.  

https://jackiepi.xyz/nca_atlas/

title: Caribbean and Pacific Islands Overview: Cross-Model Climate Projections
description:
In this video I share the projections for the Caribbean and the US Pacific Islands, including Puerto Rico and Hawaii.  For all the islands, resilience around freshwater systems will be very important, as will growing food.  This is because projected changes to life in the ocean are very serious.  

There are parts of this video that are upsetting.  Life in the oceans is already suffering more than life on land.  I explain a little about why this is so and give some background from previous extinction events to help us understand projected changes to the oceans.

Here are a number of resources that are key references for this video:

https://www.americanresiliency.org/ 
-stable visualizations & support our work

https://climate.copernicus.eu/climate-bulletins
-short & clear background info

https://nca2023.globalchange.gov/ 
-for figures & atlas

https://www.researchgate.net/publication/361134395_Interbasin_and_interhemispheric_impacts_of_a_collapsed_Atlantic_Overturning_Circulation/link/633621dc76e39959d6857360/download 
-for AMOC figures

title: Resilience Leaders: Getting Started
description: In this video I visit with a couple of our new resilience leaders involved in the volunteer ground launch.  If you're in CA, we've got an experienced role model who can show you how it's done.  If you're a new or reluctant leader, we've got an important, encouraging message for you.  And if you're someone who just really wants to get weird with it and plant the future we need, you may enjoy the final conversation in this short video.

title: March '25 Earth Systems Update
description:
Alright folks, it's time for an earth systems update.  Last month things were looking bad enough I decided to delay until we got more info.  And I'm glad I did, because we are seeing signs the global temperature spike in '25 may have been similar to what we saw in '24.  Went up the same way and so far, coming down the same way.  Let's check it out.  

To donate or to get in touch, check out my website: 
www.americanresiliency.org

Resources in this video:
Copernicus climate bulletin
https://climate.copernicus.eu/climate-bulletins

ENSO updates:
https://www.cpc.ncep.noaa.gov/products/analysis_monitoring/lanina/enso_evolution-status-fcsts-web.pdf

Drought monitor:
https://droughtmonitor.unl.edu/

Climate reanalyzer 
https://climatereanalyzer.org

Zach's ice pages
https://zacklabe.com/antarctic-sea-ice-extentconcentration/
https://zacklabe.com/arctic-sea-ice-extentconcentration/

https://discord.gg/mFxy8PZggH

title: Southern Great Plains Overview: Cross-Model Climate Projections
description:
In this regional series we're bringing the cross-model approach used in the "Lifeboats" video all around the US.  This video focuses on the Southern Great Plains, which includes Texas, Oklahoma, and Kansas.

If you want to skip the source info, go to about minute 3 to get right to the regional info.  

In this video we focus on the big edges of the problem.  Major high-end heat increases, and a serious drought trend over much of the region.  This is a region of extremes, with tough people who handle adversity well.  I hope this video helps you understand the size of the problem you're facing, and gives you some ideas around how to adapt.

Here are a number of resources I reference in the video:

https://www.americanresiliency.org/ 
-stable visualizations & support our work

https://climate.copernicus.eu/climate-bulletins

title: International Climate Outlooks: Brazil
description:
Hey folks, we’ve got a new international outlook today featuring Brazil.  This one is important for three reasons.  

-I present evidence for tipping point indicators in Brazil.  
-Brazil has a fairly stable area in the cross-model projections- important info for people in Brazil.
-The outlook for Brazil has important implications for global food systems.

Find source material for Brazil (and other countries) here:
https://climateknowledgeportal.worldbank.org/country-profiles
https://climateknowledgeportal.worldbank.org/sites/default/files/2021-07/15915-WB_Brazil%20Country%20Profile-WEB.pdf

title: Southeast Overview: Cross-Model Climate Projections
description:
In this regional series we're bringing the cross-model approach used in the "Lifeboats" video all around the US.  This video focuses on the Southeast. This region- as defined by the NCA5, our primary source material- includes Arkansas, Louisiana, Tennessee, Mississippi, Alabama, Florida, Georgia, North Carolina, South Carolina, Kentucky, West Virginia, and Virginia. Whew!  So that's a lot to cram into twenty minutes. 

If you want to skip the global update, go to about 3:30 to get right to the regional info.  

In this video we focus on factors of interest to people who love living things: the water outlook, and increases to nighttime lows.  Those factors help us understand where people will likely need to change what they grow, and help us find where the southeast is looking most stable- in east Kentucky, West Virginia, and parts of Virginia.  We also look at the twin major risks emerging in the southeast- deluge type rain, and shifting hurricane tracks.

Here are a number of resources I reference in the video:

https://www.americanresiliency.org/ 
-stable visualizations & support our work

https://climate.copernicus.eu/climate-bulletins

description: This video, a commissioned piece focused on Western North Carolina, follows up on our coverage of hurricanes Milton and Helene.  A brief intro discusses the continuing recovery from these disasters in other parts of the impacted region.

title: Action Call: Knowledge, Agency, and Power
description:
This is the volunteer link shown in the video:
https://forms.gle/YuwJ9oqLu3xRUXVD8

In this video I share information about our ground launch, focused on helping you build resilience in your community.  Many people have just recently found the channel.  This video will help us all get on the same page regarding AR's purposes, the ways I hope to lead the community, and why I believe we can do this.

title: Midwest Overview: Cross-Model Climate Projections
description:
In this regional series we're bringing the cross-model approach used in the "Lifeboats" video all around the US.  This video focuses on the Midwest- my home region!  This region- as defined by the NCA5, our primary source material- includes Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Michigan, Missouri, Iowa, Minnesota, and Wisconsin.

In this video we focus on the risk of potentially dangerous heat that is likely to impact parts of the region as we approach 2C, and pair that with projected changes to winter lows as we work to understand the potential for landscape transformation and stability across the Midwest.  

Here are a number of resources I reference in the video:

In this regional series we're bringing the cross-model approach used in the "Lifeboats" video all around the US.  This video focuses on the Pacific Northwest.  Next I'll be jumping home & looking at cross-model projections for the Midwest.

In this video we consider big picture projections around water cycle changes and their landscape implications, as well as what to expect with our best current understanding of tipping points- you'll find that info around minute 23.

title: Southwest Overview: Cross-Model Climate Projections
description:
In this regional series we're bringing the cross-model approach used in the "Lifeboats" video all around the US, starting with the Southwest.  Next region up will be the Pacific Northwest, as we work the west coast.  

In this video we consider big picture projections for water stability and heat increases across the region, as well as what to expect with our best current understanding of tipping points- you'll find that info around minute 21.  

The outlook for the southwest has nationally significant food system implications.  For our friends who grow in the Midwest, more and more states in our region are making grants available for small and mid-sized farms interested in fruit and vegetable production.  That's an important response to the serious outlooks in the parts of AZ and CA that grow so much of our nation's produce.

And here's that video I mention with practical advice for improving your home's fire resilience: https://youtu.be/g1CedJR7ziM

title: 2025: Year of the Land
description: In this end of year video I share some good news for AR.  First we do a little climate review to compare end of '24 to end of '23, and I tell a story about why I am so deeply focused on the land, based on my experiences with human cells and spaceflight.

title: Resilience & Play
description:
As we approach the holiday season, it felt important to talk about the value of play for building resilience.  Most people who are climate aware, we navigate complex emotions, and sometimes the depth of our grief can make it difficult to experience happiness or pleasure.  But we need to cultivate those capacities to make it through hard times.  Play matters!  

This video has a particular focus on the needs of children.  The kids in our lives should get some extra attention at this time of year.  

Don't worry, we'll get back to climate analysis in January!  The first regional cross-model outlook video will be the Pacific Northwest.

I made this video with JP, @LittleBigThumbs .  He's the volunteer who makes our thumbnails- thank you JP, for giving so much to the AR community!  For folks who want more game ideas, please check out his holiday video: https://youtu.be/A0ZePHs2x3I

title: Common Milkweed Seed Saving #arcommunity #resilience #seedsaving
description:
This community short from an AR member up in Canada is a nice reminder that we are coming into an important time for many prairie plants, including milkweed.  They need the cold to germinate.  Here's a link to learn more:

https://www.saveourmonarchs.org/blog/its-time-to-start-cold-stratifying-your-milkweed-seeds

title: Ice Storm- better to be ready #resilience
Building Fire Resilience
description:
Learn with me from Ash, an architect based in Boise who I consider a major innovator in resilience-focused architecture, including the use of earth-based materials.  Around 15:30 she recommends an accessible DIY project that costs about $50 and has been demonstrated to majorly reduce the risk of wildfire to your home.   

If you folks like this content, Ash is willing to come back to talk about retrofits to prepare for extreme heat in arid and in humid climates.  

Ash also recommend this video to folks who want to learn more:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vL_syp1ZScM

Ash, thank you for teaching us this week!  You're awesome!

title: Lifeboat Regions
description:
For your viewing pleasure, a boring video about the most boring places in the US.  They look boring in so many ways, under so many scenarios.  

No reason to blow up the algorithm with this unmonetized video.   I'm even turning comments off.  Don't worry- if you have a question, get in touch & I'll write you back!   

This video has some background and review for like the first five minutes, then the differences between lifeboats and destinations until about minute eleven.  After that I show some maps.  Also, I'm recovering from illness, so my voice sounds gross!  Truly, a maximally appealing production, suited to a broad audience.

title: Why Guinea Poop #resilience #gardening #manuretips #guineapig #arcommunity
description: I love this AR Community short by @RieCherie .  An adorable and effective way to get a full nutrient cycle going- guinea pigs.  Every pet owner has to deal with poop.  This is an animal where the poop can be a positive.

title: "Creepy" Crawlspace insulation #resilience #arcommunity #energyefficiency #homeimprovements
description: I love this short from Ash.  Not only does it show a great, effective way she's improved her home's energy efficiency, it also cracks me up because when I hear "creepy crawlspace", I definitely assume way more spiders, mysterious objects, maybe slimy stuff.  This is more, a vision of what your crawlspace could be!

title: International Climate Outlooks: European Union & UK
description:
Folks, this is quite a grim and serious update.  I want to warn you up front that the information this video is upsetting to the feeling person.  Might want a cup of tea.

There are some parts of Europe with fairly good cross-model stability, but the overall picture for the EU and the UK is much more difficult than we see projected for North America.

For further study, here are links to the figures, papers, and reports used in this video:

 Figures used are from the downloadable executive summary

description: This AR community short will be of interest for all the techies out there- this interesting setup gives this household info about water leaks, potential HVAC & freezer issues, and micro-local backyard weather.

title: Hazards Beyond Climate: Mosquitos & Infectious Disease
description:
When we look at the climate projections, of course living things are going to be on the move- including species of mosquitos that will be new to many parts of the US and Canada.  

In this video I teach you how to ID disease-carrying mosquitos that are moving into new habitats, as well as how to recognize diseases they carry.  Tropical diseases are likely to emerge in places where we don't have the cultural background or experience to recognize them.

I have an infectious disease background but I'm not a medical doctor, so AR community member & physician Dr. J has fact checked this script.  Dr. J also recommends folks who are interested in emerging infectious disease check out this website & subscribe to the newsletter

https://www.cidrap.umn.edu/

If the community finds this kind of information interesting or useful, I'll make another video in the next couple of months focusing on projected tick movement- how to ID them & their associated diseases, as well as any information available on treatment.

title: Hempcrete Test #resilience #homeimprovements #arcommunity
description:
Ash is repairing damage to her house with an interesting material- hempcrete.   She's heard hempcrete is a great insulator that is extremely resilient against fire.   Ash is an architect whose experiments in home resilience teach me a lot- check out her slide decks for cool ideas.  

https://www.hg80architecture.com/blog/retrofits-for-climate-resilience

title: November '24 Earth Systems Update
description:
Alright folks, this video is long and it’s got a lot going on.  We’re gonna look at current earth systems information, talk about modeling for near-term AMOC collapse impacts, do a 2C big picture overview for the US and Canada, and talk about how these colliding models are likely to interact.  I also give some information on AR’s status & direction, including upcoming changes to the video production schedule and how folks in the community could contribute if interested.

title: What is Reasonable Prep? 2025 Update
description:
This video is useful for putting a frame around your resilience prep.  Folks have told me it helped them and I hope it helps you.

For me, a lot of the practical stuff-acquiring part of resilience building is about quality of life.  Being able to take care of my family and my community in an emergency, having more give in the system for when times get tough. 

But being able to do those things isn't all about stuff.  An aircraft hanger full of freeze dried food will not help you comfort a crying child, make dried foods not taste gross, or properly put on a tourniquet. 

This video talks about my approach to building resilience inside and out, focusing on skills and attitudes as well as basic physical needs.


Here are a couple of links from in the video: 

Find a Stop the Bleed class:
https://cms.bleedingcontrol.org/class/search

Find a nutritious plant:
https://www.farmersalmanac.com/spring-wild-edibles-vitamin-c

title: New Little Blue Mushrooms #biodiversity #change
description: Maybe I'm wrong and these are lichens, not mushrooms.  But they're cute, they look just like poppyseeds.  I think they're mushrooms because lichens, the fruiting body probably would have changed into a cup-like structure by now.  This is the first new thing I've seen emerge in a few months and maybe you will find them cute.  @koicaine1230 let me know what you think!

title: Climate Outlook: Nebraska at 2C
description:
Nebraska's 2C outlook was a real challenge to interpret- I'm glad I saved it for last!  And I will tell you straight up, when all's said and done, Nebraska looks like a winner.  In this video of course I focus on the Nebraska outlook, but I also talk a little about the regional and economic stability that we can visualize so much more clearly now that we can see where and how Nebraska is in play.  

If you're interested in food systems and you haven't considered Omaha's role in our present and our 2C future, this is a state level outlook worth studying.

Here's that Omaha link for those interested in the city's resilience plans:
https://www.omacap.org/

You can find the resources I use & donate at my website, www.americanresiliency.org.   Both tabs are right on the top bar.

description:
Hey folks- this is a real short and simple video because I just wanted to talk with you. If you're looking for a one-click step to make a meaningful contribution to our network, today's a great day to download the publicly available climate information in the NCA5.

https://nca2023.globalchange.gov/

title: Climate Outlook: Arkansas at 2C
description:
Folks, I'm gonna give it to you straight.  Things look bad for Arkansas.  We're talking about multiple serious converging threats.  105+ heat, seriously increased wildfire risks, and deluge signals.  And they're all heading to Little Rock.  I sure hope I'm wrong but from my read this looks really serious.  

I made an error describing figure 2.11 as figure 2.12 around the 5 minute mark.  Figure 2.12 has extreme precipitation, figure 2.11 has changes to temperature extremes.  Honestly this is only one of the tells for how upsetting I found this outlook.  I do apologize if that gets in the way of the clarity of the information.  

You can find the resources I use & donate at my website, www.americanresiliency.org.   Both tabs are right on the top bar.

Join our Discord:
https://discord.gg/mFxy8PZggH

title: Climate Outlook: Kansas at 2C
description:
There's a lot of variation across the state in the climate projections for Kansas.  In this video I point out some of the challenges and strengths as we look to the future for Topeka and Wichita, with a few extra notes for our friends in Lawrence, KS. 

Kansas is looking at some challenging heat increases in these projections, but the drought trend is not anywhere near as bad as we saw for Oklahoma next week.  This is not a pleasant outlook by any means, but I do think Kansas may have enough edges to hold, here.  This may well be an outlook within adaptation range. 

Here is that Dust Bowl video I mentioned:
https://youtu.be/A4MmzDtyFSw

title: International Climate Outlooks: Uganda
description:
Hey folks, we’ve got a new international outlook today featuring Uganda.  If you’re interested in climate & food, this is an important one.  I see Uganda as a powerful leader on these issues.  I’ll show you why, then share information on the country’s climate outlook based on projections from the World Bank. description:
This is a challenging outlook for a state already accustomed to challenging conditions.  My goal here is to present the incoming risks clearly enough that a person who is already pretty tough can decided if projected conditions will still be within their prep & engineering capacities at 2C.  There's potential here, but the work will be hard.

You can find the resources I use & donate at my website, www.americanresiliency.org.   Both tabs are right on the top bar.

title: AR Community Asks: Tools for Extreme Rain
description:
In this video I share some resources that provide less than satisfying answers to a viewer question.  If you have a better resource, please share it in the comments! 

I share what we know about WHERE to expect extreme rain, even if that doesn't tell us how much - NCA5, figure 2.12

I show how to navigate another point & click source for climate information- doesn't get us past 3 inches, but does contain some new factors that may be of interest to viewers:
https://crt-climate-explorer.nemac.org/

I walk through how to look for amended info on FEMA flood maps (as of course, current flood maps are not so interesting for people looking for projection info)
https://msc.fema.gov/portal/search
    -The amended and revised info is sometimes broadly useful, sometimes not- but it's good to know you have the power to go beyond the visualization.

And finally I share a tutorial that is far from point & click, but does provide a great example of integrating various types of extreme rain risks:
https://fema.maps.arcgis.com/apps/MapSeries/index.html?appid=8093679c21fe4930831bc32dbf38e8f0

This storymap is also some powerful evidence of county-level resilience building in a destination area- nice.

title: Climate Outlook: Nevada at 2C
description:
Folks, I thought this was going to be an absolute tire-fire of an outlook, but I found a lot of surprises.  You won't be shocked that Vegas is projected to pick up a lot more days over 105 by 2C, but I was very interested in the relative stability I found in other parts of the state.  

For those watching solar field developments, it's worth noting there are major signs for deluge-type rain emerging over Tonopah.

title: On the monarch flyway- shana tova
Flash Drought & Flood: Includes Helene Info & a Way To Help
description:
***Please note- An edit was made to this video around 18:50 to remove incorrect information about a contributor.***

Folks, this video brings us back to a big picture, putting the pieces together around continent-level trends happening now.  But I bet many of you also need to attend to the suffering of southern Appalachia, as communities face devastating flooding from Helene.

We have an AR community member on the ground working in a group to deliver aid via the Knoxville route.  On the Discord he reached out, looking to connect with people who needed help.  I asked him, if we can help him.  Here's what he writes:

"We are flying by the seat of our pants on this one. If anyone wants to donate, @Derek-Snyder-13 on Venmo, with subject line “For NC”. 

Funds will go to fuel and food while we’re out there working, and the supplies we’ll bring. Anything beyond those costs will be passed directly to groups and individuals in effected areas (I’m 2 hours west of the effected area). 

I’ll publish receipts and records showing where all of it goes."

I will vouch for Derek.  If you want to help get help into the mountains, without any administrative or overhead costs, I strongly encourage you to send him some cash.  My family will as well.

In terms of other resources included in this video, here's the drought monitor for North America:
https://droughtmonitor.unl.edu/NADM/Home.aspx

And for the US:
https://droughtmonitor.unl.edu/

And here's that commodities article you might find interesting:
https://www.agriculturedive.com/news/mississippi-low-water-levels-third-year-barge-grain-shipping/727105/

I also use figures from the 5th and the 4th National Climate Assessments:
https://nca2023.globalchange.gov/
https://nca2018.globalchange.gov/

And bring up this article in Nature:
https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-024-07878-z

title: Climate Outlook: Mississippi at 2C
description:
Shocker- Mississippi looks hot!  But let's get past that uninteresting revelation.  

In this video I don't mean to minimize the heat risks we're likely to face in Mississippi, but it's worth noting.  The projections are showing greater increases in heat duration than heat intensity.  I am very interested in the excellent potential for landscape stability in large parts of this state.  Mississippi is looking better than either Louisiana or Alabama.  Our many AR community members in Mississippi, from Tupelo to Vicksburg to Biloxi, should find this an interesting video.  There is some fascinating resilience potential in the ancient landscapes of this beautiful state.

You can find the resources I use & donate at my website, www.americanresiliency.org.   Both tabs are right on the top bar.

title: Canada Update
description:
Folks, please take this update for Canada as an offering from a friend to a friend.  This is different from my other videos, it's looser and more extrapolative, and I hope you will listen to it with that understanding.  

There has been confusion in the community here about if Canada updated its 2019 projections.  Although Canada has put out a lot of new climate info on current adaptation work, the bottom line is, the projections have NOT been updated.  But the changes in the US projections from the NCA4 to the NCA5 have been big, with big probable impacts for Canada.  In this video, I try to tell you that story.

title: Earth Systems Update- September 2024
description:
As we move into the autumn of '24, I think it's important to look again at the ways patterns have changed in earth systems since late spring of '23.  When we talk about climate, we tend to emphasize warming and the intense storms we are experiencing.  That's legitimate, of course.  But to understand the problem in a deeper way, we should explore at the ever-increasing pile of evidence that we are experiencing systemic pattern shift.  

Here are the information sources used in this video, and a couple of my videos I might recommend.

https://climatereanalyzer.org/
https://zacklabe.com/antarctic-sea-ice-extentconcentration/

Paper available through the kindness of one of the authors, Taschetto, right here: 
https://www.researchgate.net/publication/361134395_Interbasin_and_interhemispheric_impacts_of_a_collapsed_Atlantic_Overturning_Circulation/link/633621dc76e39959d6857360/download

title: Climate Outlook: South Carolina at 2C
description:
We've got some serious challenges building in parts of South Carolina, and potential opportunities emerging in others.  When I checked out the details for Myrtle Beach, I was surprised how steady it looks in the near term- a nice thing to see for a place that is special to so many people.  However, the situation looks quite grim for Charleston, and I am very concerned about extreme stacked threats as you approach the mountains.  Much of Appalachia is exceptionally stable, but as you get up in elevation in South Carolina, we are looking at compounding risks.

title: Climate Outlook: Tennessee at 2C
description:
The NCA5 projections do give us some meaningful new information for Tennessee.  We see some improvement in the outlook for the higher-elevation parts of the state, and we've got a clearer picture of the hot-season extension facing the west.  This outlook contains details for Memphis, Chattanooga, Nashville, and Knoxville- but the sleeper hit is really the country in central Tennessee, outside of Murfreesboro.  You all are looking nice.  

Across the state, the main challenges emerging are a longer, hotter summer, and deluge type rain.  Towards the end of the video, I recommend some destinations if you're looking to move.  But if you want to stay in Tennessee, I think you've got a situation where resilience building is doable.

title: Food Resilience: Realistic Concerns
description:
I've been thinking a lot about crop production and the commodities market lately.  There's a push to get everyone freaked out about climate and crop failure.  And don't get me wrong, we are seeing crop failure.  But why isn't it touching commodities prices?  

To me, it seems wise to address emotion and systems elements when we think about food resilience.  We must not let fear distract us from what's happening on the ground now, or stop us from building the systems we need to sustain our communities.

Northern California at 2C
description:
California is the only state we're splitting in this series.  Southern California was released on July 25th.

In Northern California we find our "best-shot" area, the region of the state with the most potential for building long term resilience.  This region begins south of the Bay Area at about Half Moon Bay, extends to the eastern edge of about Napa, and returns to hug the coast all the way up to Eureka.

Alongside this hopeful region, we also find a lot of serious emerging hazards.  The Central Valley looks very rough in these projections, although we do not see any additional deluge hot spots forming up north of Bakersfield in the valley.  The Sierras, my family's home, are also looking very bad.  Northeast California is also facing what looks like a terribly high rate of change.    

Northern California is also where we find the third tipping point of the west.  We discuss the other two in the videos for Oregon and Utah.  You will see, California has a choice to make, with far-reaching outcomes.  

Here's a link to the NCA5:
https://nca2023.globalchange.gov/

title: Southern California at 2C
description:
California is the only state we're splitting in this series.  Northern California's outlook will drop August 1st.  

Southern California's outlook is quite serious for LA, Bakersfield, Blythe, Imperial, and other inland communities.  I know we have quite a few people concerned about San Diego, but San Diego looks surprisingly okay at 2C, as do many of the other coastal communities.  

There are layers of challenge here, including very severe heat increases, drought trend, and more intense, more irregular atmospheric rivers.  We also see a very intense hot spot for deluge-like precipitation appear over Bakersfield.

title: Utah 2C Climate Outlook: NCA5 Update
description:
In the NCA5 we see a much larger change in the projections for Utah than other states in the region.  In this video, we investigate the ominous high-change blob centered over Utah in the updated national climate assessment, and present the tipping point type risks unfolding around the Great Salt Lake.

I heard from many people on the ground regarding my NCA4 Utah video.  The feedback was overwhelming- people did not think the NCA4 projections were bad enough to account for the change they were already experiencing.  This feedback was consistent and unique to Utah- leading me to believe something is seriously going on there.  The community feedback is very important to our understanding- please let me know if you think the NCA5 projections are more in-line with your perceived rate of change.

Here's a link to the NCA5:
https://nca2023.globalchange.gov/

To Dustin's Toolset:
https://public.tableau.com/app/profile/dustinrathke/viz/AmericanResiliency-v3/WBTRiskLevels?publish=yes

And to the paper I used for images and information regarding the Great Salt Lake, with appreciation to Abbot, Baxter, Busche, and Freitas for their important work:

https://www.researchgate.net/publication/366876763_Emergency_measures_needed_to_rescue_Great_Salt_Lake_from_ongoing_collapse

title: Dust Bowl: Emerging Threat, History, & Personal Impact
description:
During & after the production of the 2C Oregon outlook, I had many conversations about the Dust Bowl with folks in the AR community.  I was encouraged to share this story and I thought, well, probably I should.  But, for me, the Dust Bowl is a personal story, so this is a bit different from my other videos.  Hopefully it is helpful to someone.  This is not monetized content.  If it is helpful to you, take this one as a gift.

https://e360.yale.edu/features/as-the-climate-warms-could-the-u.s.-face-another-dust-bowl

title: Oregon 2C Climate Outlook: NCA5 Update
description:
In the NCA5 outlook for Oregon we issue our first battle cry, recognizing those who choose to fight for the soil of the Willamette Valley.  Their work will matter to us all, as the information we can gather from the NCA5 shows Oregon facing an extraordinary level of change.  Only the work we do on the ground can protect Oregon's precious soil.  If the soil of Oregon is allowed to be exposed and uncared for during the rapid landscape transformation ahead, we could see a terrible dust bowl emerge. 

The dust bowl of the 1930's was a preventable disaster.  It hasn't happened again.  We could stop a new dust bowl from rising out of Oregon.

It's worth noting, there are gems in Oregon, too.  I'm gonna get you all the information you need to understand Oregon's outlook at 2C.  Bunch of resources below:

Here's a link to the NCA5:
https://nca2023.globalchange.gov/

title: Resilience News Update: Tornadoes & H5N1
description:
Folks, thanks for caring if I got tornadoed this weekend!  I am just fine and I am taking a short break from planting to get you a little news update on tornados and how tornado alley is likely to shift.  

I also feel like enough people have asked me, I'm gonna give you hopefully a 1 time H5N1 update.  H5N1 is a real threat but we don't need to panic about it full time.  I'm telling you two gates to watch for taking action, and I recommend you engage in a reasonable amount of general resilience preparation- not specific to this threat.

Watch what I mean by reasonable prep here (older video, I still abide by these boundaries myself)
https://youtu.be/KdR3UWpY5FQ

description:

title: Prairietown Dreaming: Is the State In Your Pants?
description:
Thanks for all the questions from last Monday's Prairietown Dreaming video, where I invite you to consider a high-capacity, highly resilient destination region.  The Prairie Pothole region models pretty well to 4C, so if you're a person who loves landscape restoration and wants to do work in a place where the work could last, this is an important region!

I've got lots of viewer questions I'm researching.  This week, we're talking about how intrusive the three state governments in this destination region might be regarding sex & identity issues.  Let's learn a little more about the region's natural character and state legal frameworks.  We'll bring it together with cultural notes, sharing our perception of what the vibe is on the ground regarding these issues.  

Resources:
Gay rights maps
https://www.lgbtmap.org/equality-maps
https://www.aclu.org/legislative-attacks-on-lgbtq-rights-2024

Reproductive Rights maps
https://reproductiverights.org/maps/abortion-laws-by-state/
https://www.plannedparenthoodaction.org/abortion-access-tool/US

title: Prairietown Dreaming: Let's Talk about 4C
description:
If you follow the climate news, you know we're in a time where incoming information should cause us to change our thinking.  That's why me and my husband Mike are sitting down with you today to start a conversation about the Prairie Pothole Region, the most resilient destination area in the country, with the best intake capacity.  

Why are those things both true?  Because the climate here is already terrible! If you are considering joining us here, we want to answer your questions about the place.  We hope to continue this conversation on Mondays this March, and we want to hear from you.

Forgot the Discord invite!  This'll work for a few days

title: Hurricanes, AMOC, and Wind Maps- Oh My!
description:
This intensely nerdy video is here to answer your top recent questions about hurricane outlooks and AMOC modeling.  We start with some info on the near-term hurricane outlook.  If you want to get straight to the AMOC paper- big thanks to DJ Jablonsky for finding this gem- jump about 4 minutes in.  This gives us a LOT more details about what is modeled to happen in the first 10 years after AMOC turns off, both regionally in the US and around the globe.

Paper available through the kindness of one of the authors, Taschetto, right here:

https://www.researchgate.net/publication/361134395_Interbasin_and_interhemispheric_impacts_of_a_collapsed_Atlantic_Overturning_Circulation/link/633621dc76e39959d6857360/download

title: North Carolina 2050 Climate Forecast: 2023 Update
description:
The outlook for North Carolina is unusually dynamic, with highly localized challenges and opportunities.  You're looking at relatively small seasonal changes in the mountains, but seriously intense storm increases.  By the coast, you're projected to experience pretty high sea level rise, but you'll see that historic communities are looking pretty good, with way less direct damage to the Outer Banks than I expected.  Overall, North Carolina's resilience potential is good.  Understanding and preparing for our climate future will help North Carolina stay strong!

Many people promote Michigan as a climate haven, let's check out the projections in the latest federal climate report, see how that squares up.  

The new projections for Michigan are showing some real differences from the last report.  This video contains detailed information about changes to the winters, where we expect to see the biggest storms, and the projected increased risks around serious wildfire.  The challenges are serious, but I would not count Michigan out.  People looking for a destination with mild winters should check out this unexpected outlook.

title: Winter Garden: Parsley from Seed #gardening #resilience
description: I cook with a lot of parsley.  Parsley has a two year life cycle, you can see the plants that have gone to seed and all their babies!  The seeds fell early enough that I am harvesting winter parsley.  I'll leave plants with strong-looking root systems alone.  That way, they'll be the first herbs to wake up in the bed in the early spring.

title: Winter Garden: Bok Choi #gardening #resilience
description: Many cabbage-type plants can handle intense frost and keep on growing.  This bok choi is a nice example- we've had quite a few hard frosts and several snows, but it's still growing strong!

title: Climate Resilience: Talking with Children
description:
I made this short video based on a community member's request.  Kids aren't scared of the same things we are.   If you start local, with expected on-the-ground changes in your area, you may be surprised how differently kids process this information.   They're not as scared by the changes as adults tend to be.  

I give some insight from my background working with thousands of children in various educational settings, and some tips for ways to help the children in your life build healthy personal resilience.

title: December Garden Tomatoes! #foodstorage #gardening #resilience
description: Where I live there's usually a hard frost in mid-October.  I strip my tomatoes before the frost and put everybody in a ripening basket, no matter how green or puny.  Today it's December 1st and they're still doing great!  No rot, nice ripe tomatoes, still have a pretty solid garden flavor.  I'm linking this to the short I made of the full basket- gives you a sense of how many of them have already ripened and been eaten.

title: Net Zero 2050: Implications and Latest Figures
description:
In studying the NCA5 I was able to really expand my understanding of Net Zero 2050.  I think there's some elements of this plan you should also understand, because there's a lot more implied changes to daily life than I think most people have on their radar.  Check it out, there's some positive stuff, there's some hopeful stuff, there's some stuff that gives me cause for concern- I think it's important background to a resilience approach.

https://nca2023.globalchange.gov/all-figures/
All of this is from Chapter 32.  Read it for more context!!

https://insideenergy.org/2017/01/12/energy-explained/
This is the comparison figure I use.

title: Resilience & Gratitude
description:
American Resiliency is a nonprofit, this is a Giving Tuesday video, let me tell you about our mission.  We are very close to getting this operation off the runway so I can continue being your mad scientist well past our current Sept. 2024 end date.  

Here are some of the links I visit in today's video, for those interested:

Hawaii figure is 30.11 in the 5th NCA: https://nca2023.globalchange.gov/
