title: Tasty Tiny Cactus Fruit!  Let's Pick Another One #cactus
description: This experiment turned out awesome!  What an adorable, tasty fruit!  I pick one more- the rest, I'll let ripen, maybe see if I can grow another cactus from seed.  I received this cactus years ago as a baby prop from a family friend.

title: Cactus Fruit: First Harvest #cactus
description: Thanks to advice here I am going to try to eat this cactus fruit.  You can watch while I pick the first one.  It's so cute!

title: Community Chat: Figures from the NCA5
description: Thanks to everyone who joined me today- we spent an hour looking at figures from the NCA5.  I was glad to see that other folks had some of the same questions and concerns I felt over these first few days exploring the document.  We spend a fair amount of time talking about the new water projection information.  If we can get a handle on that information, it could be critical for addressing questions about regional and local carrying capacity.

title: Caves of Doom
description: We focus a lot on the future here on this channel- for this video, I learned about some work being done to explore America's climate past.  This video is about evidence coming out of the caves of Missouri, showing thousand year cycles of intense change.  I thought it was pretty cool!  Lines up with other things I've learned about our climate past and cycles of change, let me tell you about it.

title: Cute Fruit: Can I Eat This?
description: I don't even know what type of cactus this is.  I've had it for five years, it's never made fruit before.  The fruit looks like delicious candy!  Does anyone know what it is?  Will it poison me?

title: Native Food- American Chestnut #resilience #nativeplants #nativefood
description:
There are not a lot of these trees alive, but they used to be a major, major source of food in North America.  I could be wrong, but I think this tree is a genuine American Chestnut.  I picked up a couple of leaves to show the signature canoe shape and you can see the characteristic "breaking-wave" point margins well on the smaller leaf.  

Unsurprisingly, creatures have eaten these tasty nuts!  Only a couple runty ones are left, but I think it's cool to see this rare and wonderful tree alive.

title: NCA5 First Look
description:
Take a first look with me at the NCA5.  For me, the first question was how's the hope?  How do the destination regions look?  Check it out with me as we start to unpack this new information.  Here's where to go to get the figures for yourself:

https://nca2023.globalchange.gov/all-figures/

This report is going to take me weeks to fully process.  I look forward to getting everyone updated, detailed, state-level information soon.

title: Experiment: Greenhouse in a Greenhouse? #resilience #gardening
description: In this last video from Eric's greenhouse, he liked greenhouses so much he put a greenhouse in his greenhouse.  He explains why he's doing this experiment, which I think is hilarious and just crazy enough to work.

title: Update: Superior National Forest Adaptation plan
Growing Season Extension- Timed Lights #resilience #gardening
description: Eric's greenhouse tour continues with this cool automated light and heat system to extend the growing season.

title: Greenhouse Tour- Shoulder Season Extension #resilience #gardening
description: We've got a few shorts from AR community member Eric.  I do all in-earth gardening based on plant communities, but we welcome different approaches here, and Eric's tech experiments in this greenhouse are really sweet.  Also we talked about yields and his are WAYYYYY better than mine

title: Conference Reporting Continued
description:
I thought I had a nice follow-up to share with you- a cool positive project from the climate resilience conference, a hands-on funded project!  But I tried digging into it and it turns out this is another disturbing situation.  Let me know what you think I should do.

Here's the stuff I saw referenced in the presentation that I cannot find.  I have spent hours looking and so have trustworthy volunteers.

-Superior National Forest Assisted Migration Plan.  Published September 2023, Forest Service.

-Superior National Forest Assisted Migration Implementation Guide.  Published July 2023, Forest Service.

-4.9 Million USDA Award: Minnesota Climate Smart Seedling Production Network

Here are some of the links I reference in this video:

https://www.fs.usda.gov/publications

https://www.fs.usda.gov/research/treesearch/64701

https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/forest-service-explores-moving-trees-to-save-them-from-hotter-weather/

https://extension.umn.edu/rsdp-happenings/climate-smart-trees-take-root-northeast-minnesota

title: Ripening Basket- Nice Tomatoes After Frost #resilience #gardening
description: My first year gardening I was sad because I lost so many green tomatoes when the frost came.  Now I know better and I wanted to share this basic tip for ripening tomatoes after the frost.  Pick them before the frost and then just let them sit in a covered basket at room temperature.  I had ripe tomatoes from my garden until the second week of December last year using this technique.  They're not as good as summer tomatoes, but they're still pretty good!

title: Conference Takeaway- Prepare Now
description:
I'm shook up from my trip to Minnesota.  This video I share information from the conference as well as landscape and culture notes from my trip.  Bottom line- the landscape and culture are looking very hopeful up to Minneapolis/St Paul, and then things become much worse.  

If you want to look at a good thing, check out the West Central Initiative.  These people are getting their act together.  Great role models doing great work, they're hiring:
https://wcif.org/

These are the websites I pan over while discussing the less great news related to the NCA5:
https://www.globalchange.gov/our-work/fifth-national-climate-assessment
https://www.oregon.gov/oem/hazardsprep/pages/2-weeks-ready.aspx

title: Reed Canary Grass #invasivespecies #resilience
description: I was going to make a video teaching about this grass but then there was a pro right there lol

title: Big Northern Wild Rose #resilience #nativeplants #nativefood
description: Up north of Duluth I found great patches of wild rose- you can see, these fruits are so much larger and softer than you find in warmer places.

title: Climate Destinations and Housing: Community Chat
description: Folks, thanks for the good chat.  We had people representing many destination areas, people who have moved for climate outlook, and people who are planning to move based on climate outlook.  In this chat there's a lot of discussion about local water, infrastructure, housing, and food issues in some important potential destination areas.

title: Poison Ivy- Fall Color #nativeplants #resilience
description: At this time of year you can get a good view on the proportion of poison ivy in the landscape, as it turns red earlier than many other plants.  This part of the Nahant Marsh looks pretty overrun!

title: Water Lily Bed #nativeplants #nativefood
description: These big water lily beds are so beautiful and peaceful.  Water lilies have edible seeds and roots, and are an important traditional food plant in the Midwest.

title: Nahant Marsh #nativeplants
description: A peaceful native landscape on the edge of the Mississippi River

title: Fire Resilient Prairie #resilience #prairie
description: Native prairie plants don't mind extreme cold, extreme heat, drought, or even being lit on fire.  Check out this restored prairie just a week after a controlled burn.

title: Global to National 2050 Overview: Refresh Before Updates
description:
This week let's review the global and national outlook as we get ready for the release of the 5th National Climate Assessment next month.  I want to make sure I can easily recognize what looks different in the upcoming new projections.  If you're newer to the channel, this is a good opportunity to get caught up on our current understanding based on high-consensus international and federal reports.  

I look real sad in this video.  I am an American Jew.  My family is close to many people who were murdered or taken hostage in Israel this terrible week.  To me, it is important that even in the face of these terrible things, we do not take our eyes off climate.  Climate is the deepest threat we face.

title: Search & Destroy: Tree of Heaven #invasivespecies #resilience
description: This is a great moment in the Midwest to ID invasive and toxic Tree of Heaven.  This plant looks so much like native Black Walnut, but Black Walnut turns color earlier in the fall, letting you make a positive ID at a distance.  You can also see an evident tell in the color of the stems.  Special thanks to my friend Tiffany for the murder assist.

title: Stop this Waterfall! #resilience #flashflood
description: This awesome video shows a great practical intervention by AR contributor & volunteer Sarabeth P.  Lots of places with great climate outlooks are facing increased risks of flash floods like these, but we can take action.

title: Fact Check: National Climate Resilience Framework
description:
There've been some big federal climate resilience announcements in the last couple of weeks.  If you haven't heard of them, you're not alone.  And as I looked through them, I got real cheesed off.  I highlight some of the reasons why, which highlight the real need for continuing and developing our work here with AR.  

If you're interested in signing up for the climate corps, here's the form:
https://www.whitehouse.gov/climatecorps/
And if you'd like to see the federal announcement yourself, here's a link to the PDF:
https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/National-Climate-Resilience-Framework-FINAL.pdf

title: Migrating Monarchs, 2023 #resilience #monarchs #butterfly #gardening
description: At least a hundred monarch butterflies have moved through my yard today, and now many are roosting in the trees for the night!  I feel so happy to have these guests.  Monarchs began naturally reproducing on the property last year in the final generation.  This year, we have seen naturally reproducing monarchs emerge throughout the growing season.  But we've never seen this kind of action during the migration before!  Let's hope it's the first of many years supporting the monarch flyway.

title: Collecting Prairie Seeds #prairie #resilience
description: These are some of my favorite seeds to collect- great sensory experience.

title: Ground Cherry Harvest- Cute Fruit!  #nativeplants #nativefood #resilience
description: We took a look at these volunteer ground cherries early in the summer, now they're getting ripe.  Take a look at this cute tomatillo-like fruit.

title: Bugs, Disease, & Climate: Understanding my Focus on Cold
description:
I get a lot of viewer questions asking why I don't focus more on climate destinations that would have nice climates- mild winters, places normal people want to live!  I thought about this and it really has a lot to do with my background related to microbiology and disease.  I share my thinking about bugs, disease, and climate in this video, where we'll tie climate projections to the outlook for human and plant disease.

Here's the plant hardiness zone viewer if you want to look at change where you live!

https://usfs.maps.arcgis.com/home/webmap/viewer.html?webmap=611d3e5ac1774a21a6ff55aceb8f588c

title: Shoulder Season Test Crop: Geechee-Gullah Cowpea  #resilience #gardening
description: Thanks to Jace, a friend I met in the AR community, we're checking out a cool test crop from the Caribbean.  This heritage cowpea was sent to me in an envelope with seeds mixed together that had been stored in different conditions, from frozen to room temp.  These seeds had a near hundred percent germination, so I guess they're tough enough, they don't care how you save the seeds.  We know they are resilient against drought and heat, let's see if they can manage to reproduce in an extended but still tight shoulder season in Eastern Iowa.

title: Restored Prairie at Full Height- Turkeyfoot #nativeplants
description: Prairie plants take a while to reach maturity.  They need time to get their roots in.  Here is a nice mature local prairie- thanks to my husband for serving as a height reference.  A mature prairie is taller than an adult man!

title: Making Jam from Wild Fruit
description: I felt cranky and gross and I didn't want to make science-type content today, so I made jam.  Next week, I'll get back to work.  This week, you can come hang out in my kitchen a little bit if you want.

title: Acorn Assortment: Not an Easy Nut #nativefood #nativeplants #resilience
description: I thought it was kinda cute to see how different the acorns are just in my little wood- different oaks, different acorns.  Although this is about the easiest nut to find and get out of the shell, they have to be processed before they're safe to eat.  Other common native nuts, like walnut and hickory, are a pain to get out of the shell, but safe to eat once you do.

title: Bumblebee Party! #bees #resilience
description:
With the drought here in Iowa, many late summer flowers did not bloom this year.  The ones that have are full of hungry pollinators!  I enjoyed sitting with these very large bumblebees this morning, I thought I'd share them with you.  

The bees are feeding on hosta flowers.  Hostas are not a native plant, but they can sure take a beating.  I don't have the heart to replace these reliable, resilient plants.

title: Shagbark Hickory: Easy ID, Good Nuts #nativefood #resilience
description: Keep an eye out for these trees in your local woodland, they've got a pretty broad range.  I like to go hiking in winter to identify the trees from a distance, then come back when it's time for nuts.

title: Wild Rose Hips: Safe, Tasty Vitamin C #nativefood #resilience
description: This is a mature wild rose- easy plant to identify in any season.  As roses get gigantic, they bear more and more fruit!  The hips have a lot of seeds but I think they taste wonderful.  They are very healthy for you; an important traditional food for winter vitamin C.

title: Thinking about 2024: What is Reasonable Preparation?
description:
This is a longer and more serious video, talking about what makes sense when we think about building resilience for the near future.  I share the scenarios for which I prepare, my mindset behind my preparations, and the sort of goals I recommend for people who are just starting out.  


If you are interested, this is the most recent update from NOAA about the current El Nino system:
https://www.cpc.ncep.noaa.gov/products/analysis_monitoring/lanina/enso_evolution-status-fcsts-web.pdf

title: Jewelweed: Gentle, Safe, & Strong #nativeplants #nativemedicine #resilience
description:
Jewelweed is one of my favorite wild plants.  So beautiful, gentle, and effective- a wonderful treatment for any topical itch that is powerful and safe.  Many people say that jewelweed is amongst the most effective treatments for poison ivy.

This is in a patch I've visited for a long time.  Jewelweed needs "wet feet" and tends to grow in low-lying areas.  The drought is really hurting the patch, but the plants are resilient.  You can see they are still managing to set seeds this year, even as the beautiful flowers have been damaged by the drought.

title: Pokeweed: You Can Do Better #nativeplants #nativefood #resilience
description:
I feel like it's good to know you CAN eat pokeweed but seriously, let's keep up our standards.  This plant's leaves need to be boiled in at least 3 changes of water to leech out the poisons before eating.  

...I bet there are a TON of nutrients left after all that boiling.  Areas where there are traditions of eating pokeweed are almost all areas where, by spring, you are ready to eat anything green.  Across much of the North America I would recommend plantain or dandelion as much healthier, safer, early spring alternatives for poke.

title: Community Hangout: Planning for Year 3
description:
This community hangout was great!  Some new folks joining us today with great strengths and ideas.  Around minute 15 I remembered to record in gallery view, which will allow you to see everyone at once (and sometimes also dogs).

Our big takeaways:
1. We want more community-sourced shorts.  Everyone wants to see what everyone else is doing to build resilience.  It doesn’t need to be perfect- we can have fun here!  
2. As we get ready for the next generation of state level forecasts, I want to make sure the forecasts have the types of info you need.  We had great insights for that work in this conversation, with a focus on including:
-pollution and well information
-information as to legal water rights and rainwater collection
-state GIS and state Ag Extension connections when available
-more info to help visualize climate analogs- what it will look and feel like in the state by 2050!
3. We also talked about doing more to network, both online in the creator space and on the ground at the local government level.  I will be making some videos to help you get ready to talk with people on the ground, with communication tips to help build the kind of healthy connections and relationships that grow space for change.

Do you have more ideas?  Drop a comment, send me an email- however you do it, I want to hear from you!

title: Another Giant Funnel-Web? #spiders #resilience
description: There's another one of these giant funnel webs on my property.  Is a new type of spider moving in, or are my current spiders just being gigantic?  I don't know but I do admire the hatchwork on this web.

title: Thinking Towards 2024: Signs from NOAA and from Nature
description:
When we're looking towards 2024, there's a real intersection between climate and weather.  We know that El Nino is going to have big impacts, and we know we're dealing with climate trends alongside that.  What does all this mean for the next few seasons?  As you'll see, I'm in an area where NOAA has no advice, so we'll go out in my yard and look at what the plants are saying.  Feel free to make fun of these folk traditions if they prove wrong in the spring!  And if you have similar traditions in your area, I'd be very curious to hear about them.

Here's a link to Zach Labe's wonderful climate visualizations:
https://zacklabe.com/global-sea-ice-extent-conc/

And to the NWS/NOAA seasonal page:
https://www.weather.gov/hun/climateforecast

title: Biggest Spider Trap Ever #permaculture #spiders #resilience
description:
I was just out watering and I found this HUGE trap.  I have plenty of funnel web spiders around here, but this is like 3-4x bigger than their usual traps.  And I don't know WHAT is up with the stick.  I thought this was hilarious!

#shorts

title: How Will Hurricane Tracks Change?  Long Range Outlook
description:
I haven't heard a lot of mention around how perfectly Hurricane Idalia has followed the models for emerging inland hurricane tracks around the warming Gulf.  Let's take a look here with a figure from the National Climate Assessment.  

We see conserved projections for new likely hurricane tracks moving just as Idalia has, as well as an emerging threat for inland tropical storm movement up into Arkansas through the western Bayou.  Hurricane danger looks to be intensifying in the Caribbean and south Florida.  

There are some positives in the outlook- it appears dominant hurricane tracks will move a bit away from New Orleans and Mobile, and that much of Texas may also see some threat reduction.  Fingers crossed!

Download a copy here:
https://nca2018.globalchange.gov/downloads/
This figure's on 1492 of the full report.  You can zoom in on it to pretty fine detail if you want to check it out yourself.

title: Rainbow Corn Reveal- Secondary Ears #shorts
description:
I let my kids open the primary ears, but they didn't find all the secondaries.  Let's check those out together!

#shorts 
#gardening 
#nativefood

title: Volunteer Call:  Help Me Get Control of the Ads
description:
This could be the week you give me the power to turn the ads down.  Right now, the videos on this channel have a ton of stupid ads.  I don't have any control over them.  But if you help me get through this last gateway on the platform, I'll have more control over how many ads are on my videos.  

In this video I explain how a grant from google is helping drive the recent growth on this channel.  But the annoying ads are making it harder for people to access information than it should be!   This is the week where your help can make a critical difference.  We're real close to unlocking advertising controls.  You can get me through the gate.

title: Nighttime Prairie Sounds- Listen #shorts #prairie
description:
My prairie is becoming very active at night.  I began my restoration project because I wanted to do something to help fight insect collapse- make some habitat.  I like to go out there at night and listen to the sounds that weren't there before.   

#shorts

title: Recognize Danger: Deadly Nightshade #resilience #gardening
description:
If you are new to gardening you need to be able to identify this deadly plant.  It looks a LOT like a potato.  Deadly nightshade is so poisonous that when potatoes first arrived in Europe no one wanted to try them.  Any plant that sullies the reputation of potatoes is no good in my book.  

I call it deadly nightshade in the video and that's how it's known in my region.  But I did a little research before posting and from the flower shape this plant is probably bittersweet nightshade- which is also lethally poisonous.  There are several related dangerous species.  Don't get trolled into eating any of their fruits! 

#shorts 
#gardening 
#resilience

title: Basement Update: Antarctic Sea Ice Anomalies
description:
As we continue to keep an eye on the unfolding ocean temperature story, I wanted to share some alarm bells that are going off related to data from the Antarctic.  I've been thinking about this for some time and yesterday I found Zach Labe's data visualizations- they were what I needed to help tell you this story.

Zach is a postdoc with NOAA- I want to thank him for his amazing work!  I used visuals from these particular pages:

https://zacklabe.com/antarctic-sea-ice-extentconcentration/

https://zacklabe.com/global-sea-ice-extent-conc/

But I would recommend poking around on his website there and exploring more.

title: Native Plants: Horse Nettle #resilience #gardening #nativeplants
description:
We are not on horse nettle's list of priorities.  This plant provides important food to all kinds of living things, but not us!  Horse nettle is poisonous to humans and can be very hard to eradicate from the garden.  In natural landscapes it is balanced and lives as part of a healthy diverse plant community.  Honestly, I admire horse nettle's vibe.

#shorts 
#nativeplants
#resilience

title: Native Plants: Morning Glory #resilience #gardening #nativeplants
description:
Morning Glory is a powerful native medicinal plant that is also a bit of a problem child.  This vine will overrun many landscapes.  Here morning glory is helping me eradicate a more troublesome non-native, reed canary grass.  

#shorts 
#nativeplants 
#resilience

title: Community Hangout: Heat Resilience for the Home & Garden
description:
This hangout starts with a short teaching on wet bulb temps by George Hutchinson- thanks, George!  Nice conversation with questions and comments from folks in Michigan, Georgia, Tennessee, Colorado, and Iowa about dealing with heat today & planning with heat in mind for tomorrow.  Topics range from siesta culture to Hopi heritage seeds.  

I highly recommend checking out the University of Arizona Extension office- this is the planting calendar I mention in the chat:
https://extension.arizona.edu/pubs/vegetable-planting-calendar-maricopa-county

And the University of Florida Extension Office- love this hot & humid crop overview for the home:
https://gardeningsolutions.ifas.ufl.edu/plants/edibles/vegetables/heat-tolerant-vegetables.html

title: Native Food Plants- Crabapple #resilience #nativefood #gardening #nativeplants
description:
Crabapple is a nutrient-rich fruit that tastes super gross on its own, but it's good when cooked and very useful when firming up jams and jellies for longer-term storage.

#shorts 
#nativefood  
#resilience

title: Native Food Plants- Wild Grape #resilience #nativeplants #foraging
description:
Wild grape is easy and safe to identify.  You can eat the fruit, although it's really sour!  Most people like it better cooked.  The leaves of wild grape are preferred to domestic grape for Mediterranean and Middle Eastern recipes.   And, last but not least, you can use wild grape as a partner to help murder your enemies- if your enemies are understory trees.  

#shorts 
#nativefood  
#resilience

title: India's Out of Tomatoes?
description: I wanted to pull some threads together related to commodity shortages in India.  Many folks on this channel are interested in climate and food security- when we are looking at impacts, I think India is the most important player to watch- and will be in 2024.

title: Native Food Plant Manipulation - Sugar Plum
description: Learn to manipulate your native plants! Propagate, graft, bind, and have fun with it! I had 1/20 grafts succeed this spring for my first try, and I'm going to try another 20+ in 6 months!

title: Don't be Afraid to Connect on Climate!
description: I had an awesome experience yesterday up in Iowa's Northwest corner, talking with regular people about climate!  It was so fun!  I share stories and pictures in this video so you can learn about the connections I experienced, as well as some of the methods and values that help me move beyond conflict.  We can work together for our future!

title: Native Food Plants - American Plum
description: North American native fruit tree favorite, the American plum! If you're interested in getting these for a ridiculously affordable price, check out your state nursery! Vigorous growing and very resilient to manipulation.

title: Native Food Plants- Mandan Bride Corn
description:
I didn't want to grow a lot of corn, so I sowed it in a circle, figuring that way at least some would get pollinated regardless of prevailing winds.  Thanks to raccoons, we've got a pre-harvest peek inside some ears.  I'm surprised how good they look!  

Also it's exciting to me that the circle method worked!  Other times I've grown just a small amount of corn in rows it has been...not good.

#shorts 
#nativefood  
#resilience

title: Native Food Plants- Turban Squash
description:
I grew these big plants from seeds I saved off a squash I bought on the roadside outside of Lexington, MI.  Before corn was a thing, squash was the original native food!  We're talking about an ANCIENT staple of the Americas.  Hard, knobby squash are one of the most resilient and easy to preserve foods around.  

#shorts 
#nativefood  
#resilience

title: Rainwater Capture - Simply
description:
This backyard rainwater capture system is made using reused materials bought years ago. It's not fancy, but it gets the job done. Systems not meant for human consumption don't have to be complex, just start capturing!

#shorts 
#rainwater 
#resilience

title: Native Food Plants - Elderberry
description:
American Elderberry (Sambucus canadensis) is a native woodland-edge shrub that is found throughout the central, southern, and eastern US. Elderberry season is beginning here in eastern Iowa, so time to get to foraging!

#shorts 
#nativefood  
#resilience

title: Choosing a Climate Destination
description:
A lot of people who email me are very focused on trying to find the perfect climate destination.  But it's just the reality that in a future of intense global change, every destination will experience some level of change.  In this video I talk a little about managing change and thinking more about to live and be of service in a changing landscape, rather than striving for a fantasy of total security.

And Jay C, I forgot to add you to the donor slide!  Thank you for being our first member here on YouTube, I'm fixing it now so you'll be included in the next video.

title: Food & Medicine: Queen Anne's Lace
description:
Queen Anne's lace, or wild carrot, is not really a native plant but it's here to stay.  This plant has spread out from Eurasia, now lives all over the world, and has widespread reproductive health uses in traditional cultures from India to Appalachia.  

I wanted to help preserve this traditional knowledge, but like I say in the video- I recommend using actual medicine!  If you need medical care and you can choose between plants in your yard and a doctor, I'd recommend the doctor.  

#shorts 
#resilience

title: Native Food Plants - Aronia berry
description:
Aroniaberry (Aronia melanocarpa) also known as chokeberry is a small suckering shrub often found in wetlands all across North America. 

#shorts 
#nativefood 
#resilience

title: Ocean Current Collapse?  What Would That Mean?
description:
If you're following the climate news you know this past week has been full of escalatingly horrible information about the ocean.  In this video, I talk about what AMOC collapse would mean in terms of climate patterns globally and in North America, with reference to this rad piece of primary literature:

https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00382-017-3756-0

Also, reminder- there's serious disagreement as to how soon AMOC collapse is anticipated!   But I've previously been too freaked out to actually look at what AMOC collapse would DO.  This is a higher level of detail than you'll find in most popular news articles, but not overwhelming.

title: Hot Spring Crop- Unstoppable Snow Pea
description:
These Swenson's Swedish peas are crazy.  I want to show you them again at what is (maybe?) the end of their production for the season.  They died back when it got over 92, and then when it cooled down they had MASSIVE regrowth.  Check out the quality of the seeds, they made, too!  These are my new forever snow pea- definitely have the resilience we need!

#shorts 
#gardening 
#resilience

title: Pocket Prairie: Year 4
description:
This is my favorite project.  In Year 4, the prairie is starting to take shape.  I know it's got a long way to go, but seeing what can rise up from the ground has given me a lot of joy.  

Helping these plants get their roots in while I've got water and time to spare is a way for me to make a pocket habitat that will withstand future drought conditions.  Restoring grassland has the potential to capture even more carbon than restoring forest, depending on where you are.

#shorts 
#nativeplants 
#prairie 
#resilience

title: First Try: Growing Mandan Bride
description:
I never grew corn before, let's see how my dumb plan goes.  This is Mandan Bride, an indigenous heritage variant.  You can see even from the tassels, it has a big range of color expression.  

#shorts 
#gardening 
#resilience

title: Baby Monarch Caterpillar
description:
Wanted to share the second generation of monarchs hatched here this growing season- this is the first time I've found them so young, they are very little and cute.

#shorts

title: Native Food Plants- Eastern Redbud
description:
Eastern redbud is a friendly tree that can give many kinds of food.  You can eat the flowers, you can stir-fry the pods when they're tender like this, or you can process the dry seeds like beans in the fall.  

#shorts 
#nativefood 
#resilience

title: 2050 Canada Climate Forecast
description:
This video gives an overview of Canada's most-likely climate future at 2050.  There's a tremendous range of change in the projections depending on region.  In Southern Canada the highest change is in the west, with milder projections as you move east.  Rates of change will continue to be substantially higher in the north than the south.  This video gives regional summary outlooks, highlights some changes for several major cities, and takes a look at North America from a perspective of emerging bioregions towards the end. 

These links are the key source text and the toolmaps used in this video

https://changingclimate.ca/CCCR2019/

https://climateatlas.ca/map/canada/plus30_2030_85#

title: Native Food Plants- Sumac
description:
Sumac is an insanely resilient plant that is also a great source of vitamin C.  Tastes like unsweetened red kool-aide powder, grows in zones 2-9, very drought tolerant.

#shorts 
#nativefood 
#resilience

title: Canada Questions- Processing Data Now!
description:
I finally found the stuff I need!  I'm current processing highest-quality available data for Canada to understand their most likely climate future.  

Let me know your questions so I can think about them while I study- and if you want to study with me, the sources we'll be using are below.

My current plan is to put out a video next week with visual summaries of 2050 outlooks for the provinces, then a video highlighting what parts & proportions of their gigantic boreal forests are at highest risk for wildfire, and what parts are more likely to be stable. 

This report:
https://changingclimate.ca/CCCR2019/
(with 2022 addendum)

And this tool:
https://climateatlas.ca/map/canada/minus30_baseline#lat=50.08&lng=-90.73&z=4

title: Native Food Plants- Ground Cherry
description:
I never ate ground cherry (or knew what it was) until these guys showed up in my yard.  Take a look, they have an interesting flavor & are a friendly plant.

#shorts 
#nativefood 
#resilience

title: Community Hangout: Ocean Changes and System Impacts
description:
We talk about big problems and big systems in this wide-ranging chat, which links current changes to the ocean to livelihood and culture, weather and agriculture, and biodiversity.  We spent some time putting these problems into perspective- an interesting discussion.

If you’re interested in looking at current data on ocean surface temperatures, this regularly updated NOAA map might be of interest to you:
 https://www.ospo.noaa.gov/Products/ocean/sst/anomaly/

title: Why Care About Ocean Temperatures?
description:
This video explains how the current weird ocean temperatures are likely to impact precipitation in the US as well as the global supply chain.

Great article if you're interesting in learning more:
https://yaleclimateconnections.org/2023/06/el-nino-digs-in-its-heels/

title: Native Food Plants- Black Raspberry
description:
Is it a black raspberry or a blackberry?  I just want to eat it.  I think there's some regional variation on what you call these spiky guys.  Here's a look at my big productive hedge.  I got almost no fruit the first two years!  They need to be cut back pretty hard to bear well- this video shows you how much.  

#shorts 
#nativefood 
#resilience

title: Hot Spring Crop- Swedish Pea
description:
I was bummed out that I couldn't get good snow pea production anymore with the changing springs.  But this variety is doing fantastic!   Highly recommend for anyone struggling with this garden problem.

I got them from Seed Saver's Exchange:
https://www.seedsavers.org/swenson-swedish-pea

#shorts 
#seedsaver 
#resilience

description:
There was a major funding announcement this week that quietly mainstreamed climate resilience.  Wanted to make sure I noted it- this is the first of what will be a lot of serious, landscape-changing investments.



These are the articles I showed:
https://www.noaa.gov/news-release/biden-harris-administration-announces-575-million-for-coastal-and-great-lakes-climate-resilience

This is the place to find a lot of actual stuff.  Check out how deep this thing is once you get into the tools.

title: Build It & They Will Come!
description:
If you make the habitat, life will get there.  Every patch of migration pathway matters!  

4th growing season of habitat enrichment- 2nd growing season w/ Monarch caterpillars.  Had two in the final wave last year.  Now four already!  Good sounds.

#shorts

title: Hot Spring Crop- Rattail Radish
description:
Hard to get good traditional radishes with a short, hot spring.  Rattail radish is an existing variety that has basically identical texture & heat to a traditional root radish.  Easy to grow, see yield here.

#shorts 
#seedsaver 

Variety: https://www.seedsavers.org/rat-tail-purple-organic-radish

title: Landscape Transformation: Contemporary Observations & Projection Review
description:
The last couple of weeks I drove through IA, MO, KS, OK, TX, NM, AZ, CA, NV, UT, CO, & NE, about a 4,000 mile trip.  In this video I share my observations about changing landscapes.  I visited a lot of high-change spots.  Some were full of visible death, some were full of changing life.  I also observed many areas of mild to moderate change, with hopes for pretty smooth landscape transitions.  

I used google maps in satellite view for this video, as well as:

The trusty heat zone viewer:
https://usfs.maps.arcgis.com/home/webmap/viewer.html?webmap=2a224eac04924285a094190c8e08a459

That cool map from Nebraska:
https://snr.unl.edu/data/water/groundwater/gwlevelchangemaps.aspx

title: Climate Resilience Careers & Science Communication
description:
This window gives a little window into careers available in climate resilience through a professional society I belong to and enjoy, ASAP.  They do a great job capturing what's going on in the field, professionally- if you've ever been curious about this kind of work, I'll show you good resources to explore.  

https://adaptationprofessionals.org/

This group provides a lot of great professional learning.  They're one of my sources for the up-to-date, high consensus climate information I break down for this channel.  A lot of the learning we do with ASAP is peer to peer, so we can gain from the diverse expertise people bring to the field.  This video includes a talk I was asked to give, to share what I bring to the table from my research in science communication.  

If you're interested in science communication you might enjoy this talk! Regardless, I think it's cool to see this evidence that people working professionally on resilience care about communication.  The professional community wants to get better at reaching out to people, helping everyone understand what's going on, getting more people to the table to be part of project.  We need everyone at the table to build our best possible future.

title: Climate Outlook: Tiburon, CA
description: This June I'm in California visiting friends, family, and communities.  Part of the reason why I can make the trip is the generosity of congregation Kol Shofar in Tiburon, CA.  To thank them, I made this video detailing their local climate outlook- which turned out to be one of the most remarkable places I've detailed for any community or individual.  FYI there are some places in this video where we pull out for a larger view of the Bay.

title: Building Your Resilience: Five Action Steps
description:
In this viewer-requested video, I talk about five resilience factors with action steps you could take, today, to start building your climate resilience.  I offer practical suggestions for building power, landscape, water, food, and community resilience.   I hope you find these ideas actionable and useful- especially if you're just getting started.

In step two- building landscape resilience- I reference one of my favorite tool collections ever, the USDA tree atlas.  Here's a link!

https://www.fs.usda.gov/nrs/atlas/tree/

title: The Southwest vs. Great Lakes Water:  Will They Drink Our Milkshake???
description:
In this video, we're sharing a story of two river basins.  The Southwest, even with this past wet winter for California, is still facing a dangerous drying trend, with big water cuts on the horizon.   Where could they get some water?  Many around the Great Lakes are pretty kicked up about the very idea that it might be from us.  Let's see if we can calm down long enough to learn what is being actually done to gather data on the Upper Mississippi River Basin, to prepare for the possibility of diversion requests.    

Here's a nice overview of the situation in the Southwest:
https://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/environment/story/2023-04-11/federal-government-options-colorado-river-crisis

Here's a direct link to the full publication regarding the Upper Mississippi River Basin
https://pubs.er.usgs.gov/publication/ofr20221039
https://umrba.org/sites/default/files/documents/UMRR_fisheries%20flyer_2023_Digital.pdf
(bottom link is one of their nice summary flyers)

title: Community Hangout: Food Systems & Climate Resilience
description:
A wide-ranging conversation bringing permaculture, tech, and biodiversity perspectives to big questions around food systems.  We had general agreement that our current food system needs change- we shared the ways we're working in paths forward, and hit on a number of practical and philosophical issues around changing food systems.  

As we were talking about the disconnect many people seem to feel from current food systems, our anonymous contributor was reminded of this National Geographic article:
 https://www.nationalgeographic.com/foodfeatures/hunger/

I remember when this article came out... it made an impact on me, too.

title: Groundwork Update
description: A quick, unscripted update about interacting in person with the general public about climate resilience.  We've had conversations with hundreds of people at community events these past few weeks.  This early groundwork makes me believe, more than ever, that climate resilience is a place where we can come together.

title: AR6 Long Form Analysis: Actual Numbers & Global Risk Updates
description: Not gonna lie, the AR6 short form did successfully freak me out. But you may recall, I was not sure how much I was being emotionally manipulated by scary colors and how much the outlook had actually changed. The longer form AR6 answered many of my questions. If you are building resilience in North America, our outlook remains extremely strong. However, the risk levels in many parts of the world have been substantially elevated, particularly South and Central America, with additional striking increases around the Mediterranean. I'll get you the details you need in this video. Go here: https://www.ipcc.ch/report/ar6/syr/ And click on "Longer Report" to follow along. Highly recommend the probability table on page 50 in the reader of that report.

title: First Community Hangout Recording
description: Thanks to everyone who came to our first zoom hangout- interesting discussion including folks who have moved and folks who are planning to move for climate.  We talked about what we're looking for in a climate resilience community here with AR, getting the word out, and as they so often do, things kept coming back to water.   Next time I'll remember to hit record before we start talking, you'll come in as people are sharing where they are located.

title: DOD and Climate: Understanding & Responding to Threats
description:
This subscriber-inspired video will help you understand how seriously the Department of Defense takes climate change.  If you know someone who is skeptical about this threat, the DOD is a source they should trust.

The DOD's response to climate is a major active focus across many lines of effort.  I talk a fair bit about how this is currently impacting supply chain issues, but there's a lot more going on than I can even get into.  This video doesn't even begin to touch on how much money they're currently spending getting the coastal bases ready.  

This is the DOD 21 report
https://www.sustainability.gov/pdfs/dod-2021-cap.pdf

The 22 update
https://media.defense.gov/2022/Oct/06/2003092213/-1/-1/0/2022-DOD-CAP-PROGRESS-REPORT.PDF

And the public-facing website- good for families
https://www.defense.gov/experience/prepare

title: Killing Heat: History, Projections, and Building Resilience in America
description:
Many people found the killing heat figures from the AR6 report particularly alarming and wanted more context.  We've also had previous viewer requests for better heat wave projection info on the channel.  This video gives you projection info and also helps you understand thresholds for killing heat, why current American heat wave records have held for almost a hundred years, and how our work on the ground can continue to help us fight the heat.

If you want to explore the US projection data a little more deeply, this 2019 open access paper by Bradfield Lyon et al has some of the easiest and most relevant general projection info I could find:
https://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/1748-9326/ab4b41/pdf

Here's some core data for the 1930s- understanding this decade is critical to understanding our climate future.
https://www.weather.gov/arx/heat_jul36

For that killing heat global figure, check out the AR6:
https://www.ipcc.ch/report/ar6/syr/


Short video on my qualifications & motivations:
https://youtu.be/7OXJ-J2SsBE
Connect with us on Facebook for in-person events:

title: AR6: New Intergovernmental Report
description:
This IPCC summary for policymakers dropped on March 20th, I see some chatter about it because it's scary.  Check it out here:
https://www.ipcc.ch/report/ar6/syr/

I hit the highlights that make this content different from that of previous reports, and why we need more information before we get too worked up.  There will be more information coming out soon.  Once it's released, I'll get you the information updates you need for on the ground action.

title: Alaska Long-Range Climate Outlook: Visual Update
description:
This video is for the more than two dozen of you who have sent in requests for additional information about Alaska.  I'll have to update this again in May when we expect a release of new consensus data, but you all clearly want this now.

The range of projected outcomes across Alaska is huge!  Get a realistic assessment of the levels of challenge and opportunity present across the state, with information on changes to the coasts, inland agriculture, and fisheries.  Lots of cool references below that you can explore in more depth.


Primary visuals are from the 4th National Climate Assessment, 
https://nca2018.globalchange.gov/downloads/
Alaska is Chapter 26

For a treasure trove of map-related Alaska resources
https://dggs.alaska.gov/

Permafrost risk map is in this paper:
Nelson, F.E., O.A. Anisimov, and N.I. Shiklomanov, 2001: Subsidence risk from thawing permafrost. Nature, 410 (6831), 889-890. http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/35073746  

Detailed agriculture modeling:
https://journals.ametsoc.org/view/journals/eint/22/18/ei-d-17-0036.1.xml

Sea ice projections on page 4 of this report:
https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/2013EF000162

title: Doom is Easy
description: Why is doom culture so strong and so appealing right now? We were just exploring the data last week- we've got to admit, we look on-track for a future worth living. In this livestream we'll talk about how messaging on climate in the 90's and 2000's inadvertently set the stage for doom culture today, and think about realistic ways to move forward.

title: Low Population Climate Destinations
description:
This video uses both most-likely and worst-case climate modeling to explore seven exceptionally stable locations of refuge.  Cool places to dream about if you're the type who fantasizes about a low-pop, sustainable lifestyle.  

You know I won't clickbait you.  Locations listed below, find out more in the video.  None of these places are perfect- we expect extreme storms and weather anomalies everywhere.  But in terms of baseline stability and potential to manage change, these locations are exceptional.

1. Olympic Peninsula, WA
2. Sky Islands, northern NM/southern CO
3. Mississippi Headwaters, MN
4. Wisconsin Apron, WI
5. Appalachia 1, WV
6. Appalachia 2, NC
7. Maine/New Hampshire Northern Border

To use the USDA plant hardiness and heat zone maps for yourself, check out this tutorial:
https://youtu.be/fEKL1mX_l3o

description:
This video is a commissioned project to help Sonoma County, California get ready for the changes that are coming.  Thanks so much to this community for their willingness to share this video, and a special shout-out to Lawrence Jaffe for leading the way.

title: Climate Resilience & Housing: What do We Need?
description:
This livestream I'll be talking about some approaches to housing as we move into this century.  Most new construction is not meeting our needs- I'll talk a little about how city-level policies are driving the construction of unwalkable developments full of giant houses. 

For most of us, new is out of the picture- by price point alone!  But if you're renovating with resilience in mind, where do you start?

title: Climate Destination Regions: The Big Three
description:
For our first video of 2023, I put together this bit to address the most common type of question I get on the channel.  Get a general idea of the climate and capacity of three decent, semi-affordable regions where you might move, and see what kind of housing you can get there for under 250k.  

When you watch this, don't think I'm saying everyone should move!  Check out your state level outlook.  Especially if you've got a good community around you, most folks, it's better to dig in and build resilience where you are.  

If you want to get a more detailed outlook for a particular area, I suggest checking out my state level videos.  Their descriptions have links for sources where you can access interactive maps and verify info for yourself.  Or email me & I'll get you what you need.

Short video on my qualifications & motivations:
https://youtu.be/7OXJ-J2SsBE

title: Growing Season Changes- Impacts on Food Plants
description: In this livestream I'll expand on the extreme weather video I posted a couple of weeks ago, and talk about implications for food plants in the parts of the country with the best agricultural outlook.

title: Volunteer Video
description: Wanted to give everyone a chance to meet some of our volunteers & hear some info on AR's plans and development as we move into the new year.  Wishing everyone a bright holiday season.

title: Extreme Weather Outlook
description:
In this video we talk about overall national precipitation trends, and check out some emerging extreme weather trends across the nation.  

Thanks to Sara Plotkin for research volunteer work!

Further detail on precipitation trends- check out your state outlook on:
https://statesummaries.ncics.org/
Precipitation maps and details are at the bottom of each state page

Further reading on tornadoes:
 Lee, C.C. Utilizing synoptic climatological methods to assess the impacts of
climate change on future tornado-favorable environments. Nat Hazards 62, 325–343 (2012). https://doi.org/10.1007/s11069-011-9998-y

Further reading on hail:
Brimelow, J.C., W.R. Burrows, and J.M. Hanesiak, 2017: The changing hail threat over North America in response to anthropogenic climate change. Nature Climate Change, 7, 516-522. http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nclimate3321

Further reading on bombogenesis:
Seiler, C., Zwiers, F.W. How will climate change affect explosive cyclones in the extratropics of the Northern Hemisphere?. Clim Dyn 46, 3633–3644 (2016). https://doi.org/10.1007/s00382-015-2791-y

title: Resilience Planning & Goal Setting
description:
If you've gotten familiar with the challenges emerging in your area, maybe you want to start thinking about how to respond to them.  Moving from recognizing challenges to building resilience is a process.  

If you're just getting started, I wanted to share a pretty basic resilience-building process that you can go through with me.   It's not hardcore- it'll help you think about ways you could start small, then build your way up.  

I talk about emerging challenges in my area, which include the potential for wet bulb temps, and how I'm building my home resilience.  I give some basic tips for other major emerging threats, too, like fire, and I structure the exercise with some worksheets you can find at the link below.

https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1HhNlvXyBvQ89Lo6FlmdwbarMxOLRhZiLwV910PuT3fc/edit?usp=sharing

title: Groundwater: Do We Have Enough?
description:
This video continues the story of our groundwork here in water.  As we focus in on aquifers, we're developing some outreach tools, learning some positive information about the local groundwater outlook & potential for recharge intervention- and working to address some concerns about modeling quality.

Anyone who is interested in reading Iowa groundwater reports, email me and I'll share some pdfs.

title: Cultivating Personal Resilience
description: So on this channel we talk a lot about the science- using the data to see opportunities.  But we all know situations where people see opportunities, and they fail to take them.  In this livestream we're going to talk about practical methods for building personal resilience- building that capacity to act and grasp opportunities.

title: Channel Trailer 2022
description: AR gives you information you need to make decisions about your future.  Our country's climate outlook is well understood by our scientific and political leaders.  You deserve to know, too.  Check out our channel for action-oriented, positive messaging.  There is hope!  We can prepare for what's coming.  Let's get ready.

title: Visual Global 2050 Climate Overview
description: This is a condensed and streamlined, more visual global outlook than presented in our global livestream.  Props to Mike G for the visual effects.

title: Crab Collapse- What Does it Mean?
description: Lot of news articles coming out this past week about the cancellation of the snow crab season in Alaska.  This is bad news, but if we look at the climate data, it's not unexpected.  This video explains what's happening in Alaska's snow crab habitat, what to expect will happen next, and puts the news in a science context.

title: Global climate outlook- Where is there hope?
description: In this livestream we'll talk about major global climate trends under the RCP 4.5 scenario- to help give some context for AR's work on how conditions will change in the US.  There are reasons to hope, and that hope is so important.

title: On the Ground: Episode One
description:
This is our first installment sharing the content and process of AR's on-the-ground outreach work.  In this video, I'll walk you through a little about my story and motivation, and I'll help you learn how to identify major resilience points in your area.  

Resources:
You can find the 50 states climate forecasts right on this channel.  In every state-level video, you'll find useful links in the description.  

Here's a tutorial to help you access the USDA climate hub tools:
https://youtu.be/fEKL1mX_l3o

Do you want to access that USGS archive with all the aquifer data?  Think twice and be nice!  That resource is fragile!  If you really want it, you can find it from the video, or you can email me and I'll give you the link.  But we're not gonna poke at that thing just for the heck of it.  

A note on my place- which is my biggest resilience tip.  Take a chance.  There are still a lot of properties like mine in the northern plains that are abandoned and messed up and they need work to even be insurable, but it's work many people could do themselves.  And the communities, they want people in these homes.  The home is the basis of resilience.  And a home you can work on, a home you can understand all the guts, that is a home where you can dig in.

title: Happy Birthday AR!
description:
AR is a registered nonprofit in the state of Iowa- here's what we did in our first year, and our plans for year two!  

If you want to support AR, we are hiring, we have a need for volunteers, and we would sincerely appreciate your financial support, with gifts for major donors.  You can donate at the top of our website, https://www.americanresiliency.org/, or through a link on the about page of our YouTube channel.  

I should have added this to the video, but in the audience stats page- it's worth noting our viewership here was at 90% male, most people around 40, towards 65% male, most people around 30.  So, we're having a trend towards a younger audience, and bringing in more women.

title: America 2050- Overview & Emerging Bioregions
description:
This is a condensed and clearer presentation of the information from the livestream on 9/8/22.  This synthesis of data from the 50 States Project attempts for a big picture view of how the land within the borders of our country will change by 2050 under RCP 4.5 modeling.  

Data synthesis was done using information from the 4th National Climate Assessment.  For specific information about your state, please search for "2050 Climate Forecast for (your state's name)".   All 50 states are up, and you can check out detailed resources and references in the description of each state level video.

Short video on my qualifications & motivations:
https://youtu.be/7OXJ-J2SsBE

title: America 2050: Emerging Climactic Zones
description: In this stream I'll be synthesizing information from the 50 states project to help us zoom back out and look at the size of the challenge we'll be facing as a nation.

title: Hot & Ready: Heat Resilient Crops Today
description:
There's no avoiding it: by 2050, we need some big agricultural transitions if we want to keep feeding America and the world.  This video gives some background about the cutoff temps for corn and soy, and some ways around the problem- I particularly like exploring low-tech solutions that are ready today!  

Resources:
4th National Climate Assessment:  (there's good detail in here if you wade through it!)
Full Federal Report: https://nca2018.globalchange.gov/downloads/

Some recently funded projects if you want to look at the high-tech side of the problem:
https://foundationfar.org/news/ffar-grants-develop-heat-tolerance-in-crops/

An example of a state-level grant to help small producers transition:
https://iowaagriculture.gov/agricultural-diversification-market-development-bureau/specialty-crop-block-grant-program

A good jumping-off point for hot-weather table crop cultivars:
https://gardeningsolutions.ifas.ufl.edu/plants/edibles/vegetables/heat-tolerant-vegetables.html

title: 2050 Climate Forecast for West Virginia
description:
West Virginia has some challenges in the future, but this is honestly a pretty balanced outlook.  The big risk, flooding, is already on the table.  Improving your resilience against flooding should be your top priority in most of West Virginia.  We're looking at some pretty good forest preservation- particularly in the Monongahela.  And while it's going to get substantially warmer in the western part of the state, you're getting whacked less hard than the parts of Ohio and Kentucky you border, so I would anticipate some migration into your larger western communities.  

Particularly if you're in the eastern mountains, get yourself as defended against floodwaters as you can- you're in an otherwise excellent location for climate stability.

Looking for access to sources?  Dig on in:
Full Federal Report: https://nca2018.globalchange.gov/downloads/
Heat and Hardiness Zone Maps:  https://www.climatehubs.usda.gov/hubs/topic/shifts-growing-degree-days-plant-hardiness-zones-and-heat-zones
For precipitation trends, scroll to the bottom of the following pages:
Winter
https://statesummaries.ncics.org/chapter/nd/
Spring
https://statesummaries.ncics.org/chapter/id/
And Summer
https://statesummaries.ncics.org/chapter/ks/

title: 2050 Climate Forecast for Montana
description:
The Montana forecast finishes off the Northern Great Plains region.  This outlook isn't as strong as the Dakotas or as dangerous as Wyoming.  There are some trouble spots in the state, particularly around Glacier National Park, where the spring floods will get really bad.  But the floods and other changes are likely to be more manageable than what we saw in Wyoming, with a smaller and less severe increase in summer heat, better timed changes in precipitation patterns, and plant hardiness zone shifts in agricultural areas that are likely to favor increased production.

In general, the outlook is better towards the eastern side of the state, and more challenging to the west.  I think most communities in Montana could dig in and build a good future in place.

Looking for access to sources?  Dig on in:
Full Federal Report: https://nca2018.globalchange.gov/downloads/

Heat and Hardiness Zone Maps:  https://www.climatehubs.usda.gov/hubs/topic/shifts-growing-degree-days-plant-hardiness-zones-and-heat-zones

Precipitation Maps & Very Hot Days Historical Data:
https://statesummaries.ncics.org/chapter/nd/
https://statesummaries.ncics.org/chapter/id/
https://statesummaries.ncics.org/chapter/mt/
(scroll to the bottom for the precipitation figures on all of these links.  If you want to look at summer precipitation trends, they're on the Kansas page)

title: 2050 Climate Forecast for South Carolina
description:
The biggest challenge facing South Carolina is flooding.  Tropical storm type rains are likely to hit the state more often, causing flooding well inland and towards the coast.  Coastal flooding will get worse with sea level rise, but it's not as bad a coastal outlook as you might think.  The whole northern coast is looking pretty good!  And the populated sea islands have very interesting resilience potential- there's a lot these communities could do to get ready.

If South Carolina can take care of its inland soil in the face of these drenching rains, the state could be in a good position for the future.  It'll get hotter, but with less relative change than many parts of the country or the region.  We're talking northern Florida hot, not apocalypse hot.  Good all-around resilience potential for the state.


Looking for access to sources?  Dig on in:
Full Federal Report: https://nca2018.globalchange.gov/downloads/
Heat and Hardiness Zone Maps:  https://www.climatehubs.usda.gov/hubs/topic/shifts-growing-degree-days-plant-hardiness-zones-and-heat-zones
NOAA sea level rise viewer:
https://coast.noaa.gov/slr/

title: Natives bees in my yard!
description:
I was excited to see this unusual bee behavior in my yard.  The bees were extremely calm, completely non-aggressive.  I think they are squash bees, which are native to North America, and are important indigenous agricultural partners.  How happy I am that they are living with me!

Suspected bees:
https://www.fs.fed.us/wildflowers/pollinators/pollinator-of-the-month/squash_bees.shtml

I like this link more, despite being less authoritative.
https://nativebeeology.com/2017/01/06/squash-bees-and-mastodons/

Note- I am not an authority of any kind on bee stuff or knowing what you are doing with habitat restoration.  My research specialty is communicating complex scientific concepts.  Restoring habitat is my hobby and I do not pretend to be good at it.  I just wanted to show off these cool bees!

title: 2050 Climate Forecast for Wyoming
description:
I try to give it to you straight, but this one is brutal.  And you know I'm a glass half full type, I do try and highlight what good news I could find.  

No sweetener, though.  Anyone interested in Wyoming should be very concerned by the projections for this state.  The precipitation and seasonality changes are coming together in a real bad way for Wyoming.  I'm particularly concerned for Wind River and for the foothills of the Bighorns.  

Every neighboring state has a dramatically better outlook than Wyoming.  This outlook is worse than Louisiana and I think is more dangerous than Nevada.  Wish I could offer more optimism- but when it's bad, you gotta know.

Minor note of correction, I got upset and screwed up the days over 90 figure, around minute 12.  I bumped them one bar too high, please subtract 5 days from the numbers I say.

Looking for access to sources?  Dig on in:
Full Federal Report: https://nca2018.globalchange.gov/downloads/

Heat and Hardiness Zone Maps:  https://www.climatehubs.usda.gov/hubs/topic/shifts-growing-degree-days-plant-hardiness-zones-and-heat-zones

Precipitation Maps & Very Hot Days Historical Data:
https://statesummaries.ncics.org/chapter/nd/
https://statesummaries.ncics.org/chapter/id/
https://statesummaries.ncics.org/chapter/wy/
(scroll to the bottom for the precipitation figures on all of these links.  If you want to look at summer precipitation trends, they're on the Kansas page)

title: 2050 Climate Forecast for Kansas
description:
Kansas is looking at some trouble in the southwest corner, but much of the state, including the most populated areas, has a pretty solid outlook.  Not too dramatic of temperature changes compared to some states, and probably no net loss in precipitation over the course of the year.

The elephant in the room is the long term drought outlook.  We've been in a wet period in Kansas for some time (believe it or not) that appears to be ending.  If we hit a multi-year drought, and evidence shows those have come pretty regularly over the last thousand years, I'd be concerned for the western third of the state.  Central and eastern Kansas- especially eastern Kansas- I really think you can dig in.  

Looking for access to sources?  Dig on in:
Full Federal Report: https://nca2018.globalchange.gov/downloads/
Heat and Hardiness Zone Maps:  https://www.climatehubs.usda.gov/hubs/topic/shifts-growing-degree-days-plant-hardiness-zones-and-heat-zones
Kansas drought and precipitation maps:
https://statesummaries.ncics.org/chapter/ks/
you'll need to scroll down.  Check out the bottom of the Idaho page for a national map of spring precipitation.

title: 2050 Climate Forecast for Mississippi
description:
The outlook for Mississippi is not bad.  It's going to be hotter, the inland storms and the hurricanes are going to be worse, but honestly it looks like there are some opportunities that could open up for the state.  Some nice Gulf communities and cities- like Biloxi- are looking stronger in the face of sea level rise than you might guess.  If the state can transition to hot weather crops and tune up the power grid, I think there's a lot of room for growth in the southeast corner of the state, and agriculturally, any state with a good water outlook could get themselves in position to take hot weather crops from California and Arizona.  Why not Mississippi?

Looking for access to sources?  Dig on in:
Full Federal Report: https://nca2018.globalchange.gov/downloads/
Heat and Hardiness Zone Maps:  https://www.climatehubs.usda.gov/hubs/topic/shifts-growing-degree-days-plant-hardiness-zones-and-heat-zones
NOAA sea level rise viewer:
https://coast.noaa.gov/slr/

title: 2050 Climate Forecast for North Dakota
description:
North Dakota, you're looking good.  There are challenges and changes ahead, but you're in a pretty sweet spot.  Many factors are converging to lead any reasonable person to see production gains in your future.  You are the most likely state to be able to grow contemporary pulse crops under future conditions- those are going to be very desirable!


Looking for access to sources?  Dig on in:
Full Federal Report: https://nca2018.globalchange.gov/downloads/

title: 2050 Climate Forecast for Maryland and Delaware
description:
The far western part of Maryland has great conservation, but in the rest of Maryland and all of Delaware we are looking at significant change.  By 2050, the coastline will be dramatically different, and many communities will need to move.  Landscapes and seasons will shift to feel much more like Myrtle Beach is today.  That presents some real opportunities alongside the significant challenges facing this region.  

This is the first time I have been personally shocked by how many communities are facing total inundation.  I expected to see that in the Florida Keys, in the Louisiana bayou.  I expected more losses than I saw in the Outer Banks.  But I didn't expect that we were going to lose so many places in Maryland and Delaware.  I would appreciate any feedback from viewers about the level of local awareness.

Script text is here: https://www.americanresiliency.org/learn-with-us/maryland-and-delaware-2050-forecast

title: 2050 Climate Forecast for Idaho
description:
If you are concerned about Idaho's water outlook, this is the forecast you want.  We put the pieces together, looking at projections for temperature and precipitation trends, aquifer health, snowpack, and streamflows.  Big picture?   In Idaho we're looking at big challenges, big changes, and some best-in-region opportunities.

title: 2050 Climate Forecast for Ohio
description:
Ohio is looking at bigger changes than other Midwestern states, with a major summer heatup in the forecast.  Parts of the state will gain up to three additional months over 86.  Pair this with milder winters, and you have an outlook including a serious risk of mass tree death and resulting wildfire.

But, it's not all bad news.  Ohio has shown an ability to make rapid changes, both with power infrastructure and water quality.  Ohio's ability to pivot is crucial for resilience.  And if Ohio keeps up the good work it's been doing, Ohio has a lot of capacity to grow.  

Script text is here: https://www.americanresiliency.org/learn-with-us/ohio-2050-forecast

description:
Pennsylvania has one of the best outlooks we've seen.  Fantastic conservation in a large portion of the state.  Philadelphia will experience some pretty serious changes, but I don't think we're looking at a long-term negative, even for this most hard-hit part of the state.

If you like eastern mountains, this is the state I'd pick, hands down.

description:
Virginia's outlook has a ton of variation within the state.  This video will show you the most conserved areas in the mountains, and also highlights the DC suburbs, the developed area just inland of Virginia beach that is struggling with high tide flooding, and Richmond- the big winner in terms of future urban opportunity.

Different parts of the state are looking at different degrees of challenge, but particularly if you're inland, so long as you know what to expect, there's a lot of opportunity in the state.  If you're not interested in the coastal outlook, skip to minute 11.

title: 2050 Climate Forecast for Illinois
description:
Illinois's current nasty climate puts the state ahead of the curve as we look towards 2050.  While other states gain deadly new threats, Illinois will retain much of its climate and character.

This video gives details on the different outlooks for the northern, middle, and southern thirds of the state.  Most of the news is pretty solid.  Chicago in particular has a great outlook, probably the best in the nation for a major urban center.  Central Illinois offers pretty good climate stability- better than either the northern or southern thirds of the state- while southern Illinois will be transitioning to a markedly different, much more traditionally Southern climate.  

Script text is here: https://www.americanresiliency.org/learn-with-us/illinois-2050-forecast

title: 2050 Climate Forecast for Kentucky
description:
Kentucky has a pretty rough outlook, with big projected seasonal changes that will lead to landscape transformation and likely contribute to increased tornado activity.  As an additional challenge, when there's landscape transformation, there's a risk of major wildfires.  

On the bright side, the state's water resources are incredible.  Active land management will be the key to unlocking Kentucky's best possible future.  With this state, we're looking at a future where those tough enough to dig in will be rewarded with landscape-level self determination.  

Script text is here: https://www.americanresiliency.org/learn-with-us/kentucky-2050-forecast

title: 2050 Climate Forecast for Minnesota
description:
You will be scared by the outlook for Minnesota.  The change is transformational.  However, there is no other state where change has come with so much potential opportunity.  Minnesota has some of the best urban outlooks in the nation, as well as potential for increased agricultural productivity.  The importance of the state's natural resources to America's future cannot be underestimated, and there is also potential for maintenance of cultural touchstones that also are important for tourism, including coldwater sport fish and true northern forests.  But man, it is going to be a wild ride.  Huge variation across the state.

Script text is here: https://www.americanresiliency.org/learn-with-us/minnesota-2050-forecast

title: 2050 Climate Forecast for North Carolina
description:
The climate outlook for North Carolina is interesting.  After seeing what happened to the Florida Keys I figured the Outer Banks would be toast- but they're not!  Some beaches will be lost, but others show excellent potential for resilience.  There's also great resilience potential in the mountains, as we've already seen in the Appalachia video.  

For the rest of the state, big challenges will involve dealing with drenching rains and increased energy costs.  Raleigh is near the top of the federal government's heat concern list- but if we get ready now for the changes that are coming, North Carolina has very strong resilience potential.  There are a lot of challenges in the outlook, but they are by and large very actionable.

description:
If you are concerned about American food security by midcentury, you want to check out the projections for Nebraska.  The state will face big changes, but the potential for increased staple crop production is huge.  While we're looking at longer summers, they're projected to stay largely under 92 degrees.  The growing season is projected to increase, and precipitation changes are less likely to impact spring planting in this state than most others- real sweet spot for the region.

description:
I know the projections you see on this channel don't match what you see in the news.  Here's some evidence you might want to consider about how big business, as well as state and federal governments, are investing (heavily) in an RCP 4.5 future.  I also explain a little about my motivations for doing this project.

description:
This deep dive into the 2050 climate outlook for Missouri explores the water outlook, potential hotspots for wildfire, and new challenges related to corn and particularly soy production.  

The agricultural challenges faced by the state, however, should be viewed with a mind towards the outlook for the country as a whole.  Missouri has absolutely huge potential for shifting towards table crops.  This state, with its ample water and good land values, has a lot of reason for hope as we look towards 2050!

This video includes a fair amount of info on the water outlook for both the Carson City area and for Las Vegas.  I knew this was likely to be a difficult forecast, but I didn't know how bad it would be.  The heat is one thing- that's a challenge we can face- but the water outlook is another.

description:
This deep dive into the 2050 climate outlook for Iowa pulls together the evidence to help us identify our main threat: desertification.  Iowa faces a more challenging forecast than some other Midwestern states, but the state's unique strengths put it in a strong position to get on top of things.  

AR is based in Iowa.  Expect to see videos of our practical resilience projects in Iowa starting summer 22.

title: 2050 Climate Forecast for Washington
description:
Washington state has an incredible baseline outlook- one of the mildest levels of change in the nation.  Check it out, you'll see a lot of hope for both the eastern and western sides of the state- great potential for maintaining the state's beauty, heritage, and agricultural productivity.  However, just like the rest of the northwest, Washington will be seriously impacted by increasingly frequent and severe weather events.  Expect both drought and deluge, increased intensity of atmospheric rivers, and significant changes in stream flow.  You can get a lot of solid details in this forecast, as well as access to reports and tools that will help you dig in for yourself if you want to learn more.

My apologies in advance if I butchered some place names in this forecast.  I looked up how to pronounce things, but I get excited and sometimes I just do not talk right.

description:
South Dakota is one of the few states in the nation looking at GAINS in agricultural production by 2050.  The climate of this state is projected to change radically in the next 20-30 years, with a longer growing season, milder winters, and substantially hotter summers.  

We'll learn about the opportunities and challenges provided by this transformational change, which will impact not only agriculture, but crucial ecosystem services for all of North America in the form of Prairie Pothole Region habitat.  If you're smart, you'll keep your eye on South Dakota!

Something fun & different.  Did an interview with my friend Jorie Slodki @TheJusticeTheaterProject to promote their upcoming play, Enemy of the People, by David Blakely. title: 2050 Climate Forecast for Utah
description:
The more research I did on Utah's climate outlook, the happier I felt for the state!  I think it's best outlook in the Southwestern region.  

Parts of the state will experience extreme change, but this does not apply to densely populated areas, which will see relatively mild changes.  The power outlook is good, and even more importantly, the water outlook is good.  Although the drought impacting the Southwest is extremely serious, Utah is going in with not only a history of careful water management, but virtually intact aquifers.

Towards the end of the video, I highlight my preferred resource for long-term food storage.

description:
Arkansas is looking at a number of real challenges as we approach 2050.  Some of the mountainous areas in the Northwest corner are looking at dramatic warming that will make wildfire a concern in the area, urban areas are looking at significant heat-island effects, and we will see a lot of nighttime warming in the delta, with accompanying public health impacts.  But we can get ready for these changes, and think about how to harness some changes in agriculture to our advantage.

title: 2050 Climate Forecast for Michigan
description:
This deep dive into the 2050 climate outlook for Michigan looks at the evidence: is the state a climate haven?  This forecast helps us understand the projected changes in summer heat, seasonal precipitation, and plant hardiness zones.  Michigan will be experiencing big changes, with winter-spring shifts that will reduce snow outlooks and impact fruit crops. When you look at the big picture, though, there are good approaches to the challenges this state faces.  The state stands a strong chance of maintaining its culture, practices, and character.  On the whole, pretty solid outlook.

title: 2050 Climate Forecast for Louisiana
description:
This deep dive into the 2050 climate outlook for Louisiana helps us understand the projected changes to the coastline, summer heat patterns, and agricultural zones.  I'm gonna be honest with you, the outlook is rough.  Looking better in the northern half of the state, but there are big infrastructure challenges.  We'll talk through them, help you get the info you need.

Little note- in the section on precipitation, I got frazzled.  The northwest corner of the state has a forecast for increased rainfall, the southwest corner of the state is looking at decreased rainfall.  My apologies.

title: New Orleans Climate Outlook: Envisioning the Future
description: In this video, I show you the science about New Orlean's projected future.  But this story is a great example of where we need to go beyond science, where we need to imagine the future we want to create for ourselves.  The future of New Orleans, a city that I love, will be decided by the choices we make.  And in the absence of those choices, the city will die.  Bonus guitar!

title: 2050 Climate Forecast for Alabama
description:
This deep dive into the 2050 climate outlook for Alabama looks at changes in nighttime temperatures, precipitation, agricultural zones, and the gulf.  I spend some time at the beginning talking about why reasonable people in this state might be skeptical about global warming.  You might be surprised by the historical data if you don't live here.  Check it out.  The historical daytime temperature data would make most reasonable people feel some skepticism around warming.  But daytime temperatures aren't the whole story.  I'll help you put some pieces together.
